"Pertamina has been negligent by not using international standard security systems," he said in an interview with KOMPAS TV. He said that since the 2014 fire there had been no efforts to put such a system in place and that regular inspections should be conducted to avoid future fires.
"Pertamina's board of directors should be held responsible for this deadly fire by being dismissed immediately," Radhi said.
An oil spill in 2018 caused a fire that killed five people and sickened hundreds in the port city of Balikpapan.
Authorities said it came from a broken pipe that Pertamina was using to transfer crude oil.
In March 2021, a fire at Cilacap gasoline storage facility at the largest oil refinery on the main island of Java
summary: At least 260 firefighters and 52 fire engines were struggling to contain the blaze in the nearby neighborhood, fire officials said. Satriadi Gunawan, who heads Jakarta's fire and rescue department, said people living in the residential area were still being evacuated and were being taken to a nearby village hall and a mosque. In 2014, a fire engulfed at least 40 nearby houses but no casualties were reported. Fahmi Radhi, an energy analyst, urged Pertamina and the government to immediately move the depot away from the nearby community settlements.

headline: With Paralympics silver, Suhas Yathiraj smashes his way to IAS archives
article:
Gautam Buddh Nagar (Noida) District Magistrate and shuttler Suhas Yathiraj’s Paralympics run culminated with a silver medal for India on Sunday, with the journey also earning him a place in the annals of Indian Administrative Service (IAS).

The 38-year-old Suhas, who was outdone by his 23-year-old top seed French rival Lucas Mazur in a thriller of a final, became the only IAS officer to have not only participated but also won a medal in the Paralympics.
summary: District Magistrate Suhas Yathiraj from Gautam Buddh Nagar (Noida) clinched a silver medal for India in the Paralympics, marking a remarkable achievement. In the final, he was narrowly defeated by the top-seeded French athlete, Lucas Mazur, in a thrilling contest. Suhas, aged 38, not only participated in the Paralympics but also secured a silver medal, making him the sole Indian Administrative Service (IAS) officer to achieve this distinction.

headline: TOI POLL: Fans say IPL should go on but it should do more to spread awareness about COVID-appropriate behaviour
article: At a time when the COVID-19 pandemic is wreaking havoc in India, there is a school of thought that the IPL should not continue. However, others argue that the league also supports an entire economic ecosystem and is also not making the COVID situation in the country worse in any way. And also that it provides much needed relief and distraction in these extremely tough times.
summary: At the COVID-19 pandemic situation there is a thought to stop IPL due to COVID conditions it is spreading from one person to another. In that case some persons argued over to run the ipl because it belongs to entire ecosystem, One thing they particularly said it provides much relief and distraction in COVID pandemics.

headline: The paradox in Chidambaram’s budget
article:
Here is a paradox worth paying attention to. Finance minister P. Chidambaram was able to keep the fiscal deficit for 2012-13 within the target he had set himself because total spending by the government was around ₹ 60,000 crore less than budgeted.
One would have expected him to build on this austerity, even though it was led by curbs on capital spending rather than subsidy cuts. However, in the budget he presented on Thursday, the finance minister has indicated he will increase public spending faster than the underlying economy is expected to grow in nominal terms.
There are no prizes for guessing why we have seen a strategic switch from austerity to profligacy: there is a national election due in 2014.
summary: A noteworthy paradox emerges in the fiscal strategy of Finance Minister P. Chidambaram for the year 2012-13. He managed to keep the fiscal deficit within his set target by underspending government funds by approximately ₹60,000 crore. One might have anticipated a continuation of this fiscal restraint, even though it was primarily achieved by curbing capital spending rather than reducing subsidies. However, in the latest budget presentation, the finance minister signaled an intention to increase public spending at a rate faster than the expected nominal economic growth. This shift from austerity to increased expenditure can be attributed to the upcoming national election scheduled for 2014. The political context appears to have influenced this change in fiscal policy.

headline: Views | Dim sum bonds in tandoori land
article:
In a move that could help them reduce borrowing costs, the Reserve Bank of India last week allowed Indian firms to raise debt in Chinese renminbi, up to a collective total of $1 billion.
Indian companies with trading and investment links with China can now settle transactions by borrowing directly in renminbi, instead of raising money in US dollar and converting it to the Chinese currency, which would be more expensive.
Trade between India and China has grown at 40% year-on-year and stood at $60 billion last year. China remains India’s largest trading partner, accounting for 9.09% of India’s international trade during 2009-10.
summary: The Reserve Bank of India has permitted Indian companies with links to China to raise debt in Chinese renminbi, totaling $1 billion. This move aims to reduce borrowing costs by enabling businesses to directly settle transactions in renminbi instead of converting US dollars, as trade between India and China continues to grow significantly. China is India's largest trading partner, representing 9.09% of India's international trade during 2009-10.

headline: HC sets aside Marketfed election
article: kochi: a division bench of the kerala high court on tuesday set aside the management committee election conducted by the kerala state cooperative marketing federation (marketfed) on january 3 last year and directed the apex society to start the election process afresh and elect a new committee. the direction was issued by the bench challenging the jan 5, 2000, government order issued under sec 31 of kerala cooperative marketing societies act nominating a woman and an sc/st member to the managing committee under section 28 a (3) of the act. the government had also nominated three members to the committee which was not challenged. the bench consisted of acting chief justice p k balasubramaniyan and justice t m hassan pillai. the bench also directed the management committee elected on jan 3 to be in charge of day-to-day affairs of the society and to carry on the administration of the society. the court restrained them from taking any policy decision. though the election was notified on oct 15, 1999, the election actually was held on january 3 last year after the court disposed of some petitions challenging the nomination of certain candidates. the new management committee was constituted on april 18, 2000.
summary: The Kerala High Court has nullified the management committee election held by the Kerala State Cooperative Marketing Federation (MarketFed) on January 3 last year. They've ordered a new election process, due to concerns regarding a government order from January 5, 2000, which appointed a woman and an SC/ST member to the committee. The court has allowed the existing committee to manage day-to-day affairs but restricted them from making policy decisions. This decision came from a bench of judges led by Acting Chief Justice P.K. Balasubramaniyan and Justice T.M. Hassan Pillai.

headline: Doctor G
article:
Typically, a film cannot be split into two halves in terms of quality
— pre-intermission and post-intermission. Anubhuti Kashyap’s film an
unwitting male gynaecologist goes against this rule. The movie is
tempered with mediocrity in the first half, while the second half
boasts of comparatively high quality content. The movie loiters in the
first half, aimlessly making one believe that Ayushman Khurana just
sheds synthetic tears and throws crass one-liners.

Uday Gupta (Ayushman Khurana) aspires to be an orthopedician but gets
a seat in the department of gynaecology and obstetrics in a local
government college. To make things worse for him, his boss is stern
and no-nonsense Nandini (Shefali Shaw). He suffers from further
ignominy, isolation and embarrassment when his classmates — aspiring
gynaecs such as Rakul Preet Singh and the YouTube sensation AiyyO
Shraddha — try to bully and rag him. Uday plays along as he sees
gynaecology as a stop gap before he can move to his desired
specialisation in bones and limbs.
summary: Anubhuti Kashyap's film, an unintentional male gynaecologist, diverges in quality between its two halves. The initial part is marked by mediocrity, with Ayushmann Khurrana seemingly resorting to synthetic emotions and crass one-liners. The story follows Uday Gupta's (Khurrana) misadventures as he reluctantly takes up gynaecology studies. The film gains momentum in the second half with improved content and character development.

headline: Who’s the ghost in Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2??
article:
Even as Kartik Aaryan, Kiara Advani and Tabu start shooting from December this year for the balance 50% of their film Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2 across Lucknow and Mumbai, an uneasy calm prevails among many actors of the film — they are actually unaware of who would play the ghost in the film.

This is not, however, a first. Actors in many Bollywood films usually do not know what the climax in the film is till they end up shooting for it.
summary: While Kartik Aaryan, Kiara Advani, and Tabu gear up to resume shooting for the remaining 50% of "Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2" in December, there's an intriguing mystery surrounding the film – the identity of the ghost is still unknown to many of the actors. In Bollywood, it's not uncommon for actors to be kept in the dark about the film's climax until they are on set.

headline: Theatres urge regulation of licences to show films
article: mumbai: maharashtra video theatres association, having a membership of over 2,500, has moved the mumbai high court urging for a direction to the centre to forthwith constitute a regulatory body to issue licences for exhibiting copyright works such as music, dramas and movies. the petition has been partly heard by chief justice b.p. singh and justice vijaya tahilramani and adjourned to august 6 for arguments. the petitioners contended that way back in 1995 centre had made a provision in the copyright act and copyright rules allowing formation of a society to issue licences for exhibiting copyright works. the petitioner alleged that till date no such society existed in maharashtra. it alleged that due to the absence of an official body, private firms had emerged on the horizon, which were charging licence fees for exhibiting copyright works. the petition alleged that asia vision entertainment cinemastar, a consortium of eight video companies, had issued advertisements claiming that it possessed copyright of 1,000 films and asking parlours or theatres to first obtain licence before exhibiting these films. the licence fees prescribed by asia vision entertainment cinemastar was rs 20,000 per annum for parlours screening films on television and rs 30,000 for theatres showing movies on the big screen. the petition alleged that asia vision entertainment cinemastar was not approved by the central government. yet it was collecting money from members of maharashtra video theatres association. in case of refusal to pay licence fees, police complaints were lodged by asia vision entertainment cinemastar, the court was told. petitioner's counsel avinash shinde submitted that the theatres had made inquiries with film producers' association and were told that no such copyright was given to asia vision entertainment cinemastar. he urged the high court to direct the union government to form a society under the copyright act to issue licences for exhibiting films and take action against unofficial agencies involved in such acts. suresh chawla, vice president of asia vision entertainment, filed an affidavit claiming to possess copyright of 1,000 films and said that his organisation had formed a scheme to allow screening of these films. video parlours in maharashtra did not possess licence to run theatres under the bombay cinema act and were functioing illegally, he added.
summary: The Maharashtra Video Theatres Association, with over 2,500 members, has approached the Mumbai High Court, requesting the central government to establish a regulatory body for granting licenses to display copyrighted works like music, dramas, and movies. The petition argues that, despite provisions in the Copyright Act and Copyright Rules from 1995 allowing for the formation of a society to issue such licenses, no such entity exists in Maharashtra. This absence has given rise to private firms charging license fees for exhibiting copyrighted works. One consortium, Asia Vision Entertainment Cinemastar, claimed copyright for 1,000 films and charged theaters without official approval. The court case has been adjourned until August 6 for further arguments. The petition seeks the formation of a government-sanctioned society to issue film licenses and action against unofficial agencies involved in these activities.

headline: In memory of the late actor Jagdeep Jaffrey
article:
Moving to Mumbai from Datia state with his widowed mother after Partition, eight-year-old Ishtiaq preferred to work on the road and go to night school.

Spotted by an assistant director who later became ‘the’ Yash Chopra, Ishtiaq became Jagdeep playing a Darwan in B.R. Chopra’s Afsana in a school play. His three-rupee fee became six and he had arrived because he could speak chaste Urdu.

A role in Sheikh Mukhtiar’s Annadaata, which impressed the filmmaker so much that he was referred for a film called Dhobi Doctor by Phani Majumdar.

Playing a young Kishore Kumar with Asha Parekh was the little girl opposite him, he cried through the film impressing the filmmaker as well as Bimal Roy, who saw the rushes and cast him as the shoeshine boy Laloo Ustad in Do Bigha Zameen.
summary: Ishtiaq, who later became popular as Jagdeep, embarked on a remarkable journey. After moving to Mumbai with his widowed mother following Partition, the eight-year-old chose to work on the streets and attend night school. His talent was discovered by an assistant director who later became the renowned Yash Chopra. Ishtiaq began as a Darwan in a school play, impressing with his chaste Urdu. He progressed through roles in various films and ultimately made a mark in iconic movies like "Do Bigha Zameen," impressing filmmakers such as Bimal Roy.

headline: Do collapsed wells portend tremors in Kerala?
article: thiruvananthapuram: the collapse of wells in many parts of kerala and tamil nadu in the recent past has created a scare among the general public. what looms large in these areas is the horror left behind by the gujarat earthquake, and many think the phenomena like well-collapse and red rain are portending another tragedy of similar dimension. adding to the fear is the divided scientific community. the two camps are sending out different versions: one warns of possible tremors and the other rules it out. to clear this confusion, the national committee of science and technology team led by vinod k. gaur will study the recent tremors that occurred in parts of karnataka, tamil nadu and kerala. sources at the chief minister's office said the central team was expected to begin the study by mid-august. apparently, kerala chief minister a.k. antony has suggested that the team examine the red rain phenomenon in some parts of kerala. earlier, the preliminary study conducted by the scientists of the centre for earth science studies (cess), central ground water authority and the geophysicists had ruled out any tectonic activity leading to the collapse of wells. the cess director m. bhaba told the times of india that the mild tremors experienced in the southern states had not caused the well collapses. nor were they the harbingers of an impending doom. heavy rain over a short period had caused the groundwater movement faster and the resultant pressure had led to the damage or collapse of some wells, he said. "the scare is unfounded." but scientists in the cess itself, john mathai and s. sidhardhan, have pointed out that the issue had been well studied in china where tremors are part of life. disturbances in groundwater are a sure indication of tectonic activity occurring in the western part of indian plate. this place is spread from gujarat to the southern tip of kerala. increase in pore pressure due to heavy rain in a few hours could be a contributing factor, not a causatory factor, it is argued. "there is increasing tectonic stress building up from within due to reactivation of pre-existing fault zones," asserted mathai. the cess team has, however, explained away the red rain in changanncherry, kottayam and some other districts last week. the brownish red colour of the water was owing to the burst of a meteor, the cess team said after examining the rain water collected from these areas. the scientists, in a press release said, "based on the analysis of the samples of sediments obtained from changanacherry and the information from the residents, preliminary hypothesis as to the cause of the colour has been derived. a meteor dashed from the west to the east and exploded over changanacherry. this happened at 5.30 am. the burning meteor threw fine dust into the atmosphere that came down as red rain. the total dust throwing out is estimated to be some 1,000 kilograms." however, the scientists are yet to answer another question that is dogging the the public: what caused the yellow, black rain as was reported from kozhikode and palakkad districts of north kerala.
summary: Well collapses in Kerala and Tamil Nadu have raised concerns, with some fearing another major earthquake similar to Gujarat. The scientific community is divided, with one camp warning of possible tremors and another dismissing them. To address the confusion, a team led by Vinod K. Gaur is studying recent tremors. Preliminary studies attribute well collapses to heavy rain, not tectonic activity. Additionally, red rain has been explained as a meteor explosion, releasing fine dust into the atmosphere. However, the cause of yellow and black rain remains unknown, leading to ongoing investigations.

headline: watchOS 6 advances health and fitness capabilities for Apple Watch
article: The new Cycle Tracking app gives women the ability to log important information related to their menstrual cycles and see predicted timing for their next period and fertile window using the convenience of Apple Watch. The daily log function enables the quick addition of information related to the menstrual cycle, including current period, flow, symptoms, results from ovulation prediction kits and other elements of fertility tracking. The new Cycle Tracking feature is also available in the Health app on iPhone with iOS 13.
summary: The Cycle Tracking app from Apple empowers women to conveniently track their menstrual cycles and receive predictions for their upcoming periods and fertile windows through the Apple Watch. It allows for easy logging of menstrual cycle details like period start, flow, symptoms, and ovulation kit results. This feature is also accessible through the Health app on iPhones with iOS 13.

headline: Politics keeps lecturers occupied
article: new delhi: students who? teacher-raj is the operative word in delhi university. involved in umpteen tug-of-wars with various groups, the varsity is their political classroom. the image of a teacher confined to academics has been shredded by their newfound political avatar. to the extent that even a critical debate like absenteeism of teachers is being dragged on, with some even supporting the truants. the crucial question is whether teachers elected to the du academic council actually work in the interest of students. "talk of appointment of teachers, principals, revision of courses... all academic matters get coloured in a political light," said an academic council member. the role: the four delhi university teachers' associations are all politically affiliated. while the national democratic teachers' front is affiliated to the bjp, the democratic teachers' front has a leftist leaning. the indian national teachers' congress and the academics for action and development have ties with the congress. student issues invariably get stumped, despite the fact that several independent candidates also make it to the council. "no group fields more than four to five candidates for the 26 elected seats in the ac," duta president and aad chairman s.s. rathi said. the rest of the seats are cornered by independent candidates. the consequences: poor quality of teaching is one of the most obvious outcomes. "the group in power influencing appointment of teachers is common," said ndtf member manoj sinha. dtf vice-president vijendra sharma agreed. "even meritorious candidates require help from these groups," he said. take the instance of an east delhi college. it was alleged that the principal favoured the induction of teachers owing allegiance to a particular group. the issue of the principal's suspension developed into a full-scale war. similar were the cases of two other principals who were accused of financial irregularities. some groups even supported them. the machinations come into play even in the appointment of principals. "there was a disagreement between the university nominees and other governing body members over the principals' appointment," said a teacher representative in a governing body. the two nominees allegedly preferred teachers with a certain ideological orientation. the posts were re-advertised in two of the colleges. it's a telling fact that varsity officials refused to comment on the issue of teachers' politics, terming it 'sensitive'. admitting helplessness in the face of policy towards teaching and non-teaching staff, officials seemed at a loss for words. but the direct impact of politics is felt when classrooms go empty due to strikes. last year's marathon strike lasted 45 days. recently, the teachers threatened to boycott examinations to press their demand to implement a promotional scheme. "it is self-interest versus student interest which now reflects on the perception of teachers," said du registrar k k panda. the teachers, on the other hand, blame their higher-ups. "according to rules, the academic council meeting should be held every month, but in the past 14 months, only three regular meetings have been held," said rekha dayal, an aad member. "how do we raise issues if meetings are not held?" she asked. however, there have been occasions where groups have been divided, ostensibly over student interest issues. take the instance of bit/bis courses. the academic council in its meeting held in october decided to downgrade the four-year courses. there were groups which opposed as well as supported the decision. "this, despite the fact that the courses were being recognised in student interest," a teacher said. interestingly, there have been instances where upgradation of courses have suffered due to ideological differences. another conflict began brewing with talks of revising the history course, with some teachers claiming that it was a bid to 'saffronise' the curriculum. "by and large, teachers have not done enough to alleviate the suffering of students, especially in terms of accountability," said sharma. teaching is also about inspiration and acting as a role model, he added. but is there a way out? "what the teachers can do is participate actively in the university-industry interaction cells. this will not only encourage research, but also increase academic involvement," panda said.
summary: In Delhi University, students often find themselves caught in the political crossfire, where teachers, affiliated with various political groups, have moved beyond academics into the realm of politics. The influence of political groups within the academic council is noticeable, affecting matters like teacher appointments and course revisions. The impact of this political interference can be seen in the quality of teaching and frequent strikes that leave classrooms empty. While some groups may claim to act in students' interests, the situation remains complex, with ideological divisions even affecting course upgrades. However, some argue that teachers should focus on active participation in academic activities, like university-industry interaction cells, to improve the educational landscape.

newspaper_name: Farmers unhappy with new land acquisition rates
headline: Farmers unhappy with new land acquisition rates
article: new delhi: the announcement of new land acquisition rates brings farmers a step closer to long-awaited compensations. bawana landowner, ram niwas sehrawat, who has been sitting on a protest dharna outside his village along with dozens of farmers for the past 40 days, says: "we were protesting to get a compensation of rs 23 lakh per acre for our fertile land. we will end the dharna in two days but there are a number of issues that remain unaddressed." sehrawat says the farmers should be given either a flat or a plot on the land which has been acquired. he says: "we are demanding this as farmers often blow-off the money they get as compensation. also, these farmers have been agriculturists for as long as they can remember and cannot take up other professions for a livelihood." a retired sub-inspector of the delhi police said: "we want the government to change its policy on acquisition. our land was acquired in 1997 for which we will get paid now. the government merely announces in newspapers that it is acquiring a particular piece of land and does not inform individual owners about the acquisition. even if the land has a ripe crop or vegetables on it, we are not allowed to harvest it. local officials come and level the field along with the crop, the trees and the vegetables." sujinder singh of khera khurd village, who also sat on the dharna, said: "the government acquired all the eight acres which our family owned. now that we do not have anything to fall back on, we are scouting for land in bareilly or sonepat." but not every farmer is as wise. bawana mla surender kumar says: "i wish the government would teach money management to the farmers. otherwise, they will blow up the hefty compensation in buying white elephants and acquiring cars. i have seen farmers enter into a rat race because of this windfall. also, the government can train them so that they invest their money in another profession or business." bhagat singh of ghazipur village said: "this compensation amount is adequate. earlier the farmers were being short-changed. sheila's stand on acquisition is right and jagmohan should not have interfered." but not all farmers think this way. many bawana farmers feel that the congress has merely implemented a position held by leaders like former deputy prime minister devi lal and delhi mp sahib singh.
summary: The announcement of new land acquisition rates is a positive step for farmers seeking compensation. Ram Niwas Sehrawat, a farmer from Bawana, led a 40-day protest to secure fair compensation. He and others are now advocating for plots or flats on the acquired land instead of a lump sum, as they've been agriculturists for generations. Farmers are also concerned about the government's land acquisition process, where they often lose their crops to field leveling. While some see the compensation as adequate, others suggest financial management training to ensure wise investments. Opinions on the government's position vary among farmers.

headline: IN BLACK AND WHITE Can NDA survive without Vajpayee?
article: as long as the nda is around and he is around, with his faculties in good order, he will head it. vajpayee has been the cementing factor for two reasons. one: for what he is, his experience and his statesmanship. and two: he heads the largest party in the nda whose membership is more than all other nda partners put together. in the three years that he's led the country, he has amply demonstrated his capabilities, and through the initiatives he has taken, he has made himself virtually indispensable. a high watermark was his initiative to hold a dialogue with the pakistan leadership. i believe the agra summit was a landmark achievement in that it paved the way for a future dialogue on a whole lot of issues which need to be resolved. i do not believe that without him this would have been possible. in 1977, in morarji desai's government where i was industry minister and vajpayee was the external affairs minister, he had taken initiatives to create channels of communication between india and pakistan. in a sense, in the area of external relations, the country has never reached a point where we stand today, with good relations with most countries of the world. i am narrating all this to make the point that he was the natural leader when the nda was formed and he continues to hold that position of pre-eminence in the alliance. the trust which various components of the nda have in him also makes him the indispensable leader. this has to do with the rapport he has established with every component of the nda as well as his sensitivities, which make him a kind of father figure. he also has the capacity to take a lot of beating where occasionally some individuals or groups act out of turn. he is a good listener. that makes everyone in the nda repose immense faith in him. i do not agree that he has either been imposed from the top or has failed in cementing differences within the nda. go back to 1967. on a call from ram manohar lohia, parties shed their mutual distrust and came together. even though the communists helped the congress to survive at the centre, a number of non-congress governments came up in the states. but lohia died soon after. deprived of his leadership, and unable to withstand the manipulative pressures of the congress, these coalitions fell apart. but lessons were learnt from the mistakes and seeds of future non-congress governments were sown. the point i am making is that we have evolved. in the aftermath of the jp movement and the emergency, the time was ripe for a non-congress government at the centre. this experiment may have lasted longer if the parties had kept their identities and formed a genuine coalition. but jp used his moral and political authority to forge a single party. also, the way morarji desai was selected by jp and acharya kripalani, bypassing the democratic process, led to the fall of the government. two leaders — as powerful, if not more, than desai — jagjivan ram and chaudhary charan singh, never reconciled to this. mistakes were made, but lessons were also learnt from them. so, many of us who had learnt from earlier mistakes were determined not to repeat them when the nda was formed. a national agenda for governance was formulated, overriding ideological tendencies and sectoral agendas. we have done well in three years and as nda's convenor, i have absolutely no doubt that this government will complete its full term. dissent occurs even in single party governments. it's in the handling that your management skills count. (george fernandes is convenor, nda. he spoke to mahendra ved)
summary:
As long as the NDA exists and Atal Bihari Vajpayee remains active and in good health, he will continue to lead it. Vajpayee has been the unifying force for two crucial reasons: his experience and statesmanship, and the fact that he leads the largest party in the NDA, which has more members than all other NDA partners combined.

During his three years as the country's leader, Vajpayee has demonstrated his capabilities and taken initiatives that have made him virtually irreplaceable. A significant milestone was his effort to initiate a dialogue with Pakistan, notably through the Agra summit, which paved the way for future discussions on a range of issues. His leadership and rapport with NDA components make him indispensable, akin to a father figure. He can withstand challenges and is known for being a good listener, which fosters trust among NDA members.

It is incorrect to claim that he was imposed from the top or has failed to address differences within the NDA. The political landscape has evolved, and lessons have been learned from past experiments in forming non-Congress governments. The NDA was created with a national agenda for governance, transcending ideological differences and sectoral interests. Despite occasional dissent, the NDA government is expected to complete its full term.

(George Fernandes is the convenor of the NDA, and he shared these insights in an interview with Mahendra Ved.)

headline: PM offered to quit as he was 'hurt': George
article: new delhi: nda convenor george fernandes saturday night defended prime minister atal behari vajpayee saying he had "felt hurt" at the constant criticism mounted against him and his office and had decided to quit. "he is an emotional and sensitive man.... if there is constant rumour against that kind of a person, who is in public life, then he is bound to consider such a drastic step," fernandes told "aaj tak". describing vajpayee as a "statesman", he said it was quite difficult to run a coalition government and "he has done it successfully for three long years". stating that it was imperative to have "discipline" in the nda coalition, he said even the decision to appoint an internal committee to formulate a code of conduct for the alliance partners was being opposed by certain sections. "if you differ on certain issue, that should be sorted out within the fold," fernandes asserted when asked about the absence of shiv sena in the nda meeting earlier this week. he replied in the negative when asked whether he would return to the government in the interim before the justice venkataswamy commission gave its findings on the tehelka expose.
summary: NDA Convenor George Fernandes defended Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, stating that Vajpayee's sensitivity and emotional nature led him to feel hurt by constant criticism. Fernandes praised Vajpayee as a statesman who successfully managed a coalition government for three years. He emphasized the importance of discipline within the NDA coalition and the need to address differences internally. When questioned about his return to the government before the Justice Venkataswamy Commission's findings on the Tehelka expose, Fernandes did not provide a clear response.

headline: Amitabh Bachchan: Goes international
article: it all started with the wax statue at madame tussaud's that indian cinema made it's way to international parameters. and now to take things a step forward the big b is actually looking forward to doing some good international roles that may come his way. "there are a few talks happening right now, but i wouldn't want to comment till all is confirmed," he is heard saying. but whatever the case may be, aby has already made a name for himself and his quality of work have by far crossed even international standards, laying its respective standard altogether, where no man has ever reached.
summary: Indian cinema gained international recognition, symbolized by a wax statue at Madame Tussaud's. Now, Amitabh Bachchan is looking to expand his horizons with international roles. While there are ongoing discussions, he refrains from commenting until everything is confirmed. Amitabh has already established a name for himself with work that exceeds international standards, setting a new benchmark.

headline: Vyas demands action against Medha, Roy
article: ahmedabad: reacting sharply to the demonstrations by arundhati roy and medha patkar daring the supreme court to take action, narmada samarthan convenor jay narayan vyas has pleaded for stern action against this group. in a strongly-worded letter addressed to the chief justice of india, vyas has indicated that the demonstration made by arundhati roy and her colleagues openly defying the supreme court's observations and even challenging the authority of the apex court "has now exposed their real face and ideology, removing the mask under which they were covered." castigating this demonstration as a contempt of the supreme court, vyas has further observed that this is not only a defiance and insult of apex court but also a challenge to the constitutionally-appointed authority showing sheer contempt towards the democratic process and the most important institution _ the judiciary. vyas said these are the same people who, till it suits them, would beg before the supreme court for justice, but the moment the situation develops exposing their real intentions they will turn around 180 degrees and go to the extent of daring the apex court. "whatever the intentions, whatever may be the cause, the buck has to stop somewhere," he said. he has appealed to the chief justice that these people, who are out to exploit magnanimity of the supreme court and want to go ahead undeterred with their plans, must be checked. he has requested to the chief justice that such people, who do not care for democratic process or the well-established judicial system in the country, may be restrained from approaching judicial or quasi-judicial authorities as they themselves have shown defiance towards the system of administration of justice. vyas said, "they have already lost their battle in the national and international fora. the popular opinion was turning against them and they are being chased out by the people from even their most safe strongholds. i think now they are resorting to these kind of stunts for the sake of publicity."
summary:
In response to demonstrations by Arundhati Roy and Medha Patkar challenging the Supreme Court, Narmada Samarthan convenor Jay Narayan Vyas has strongly urged stern action against this group. In a letter to the Chief Justice of India, Vyas expressed that these demonstrations openly defying the Supreme Court's observations and challenging its authority have unveiled the group's true intentions. He labeled this as contempt of the Supreme Court, an insult to the judiciary, and a challenge to the constitutionally-appointed authority.

Vyas pointed out the group's inconsistency in seeking justice from the Supreme Court when it serves their purpose but daring the court when their intentions are exposed. He called for the group to be restrained from approaching judicial or quasi-judicial authorities, given their defiance of the justice system. Vyas emphasized that these individuals, regardless of their intentions or causes, must be checked as they exploit the Supreme Court's leniency and seek undue publicity.

He added that the group had already lost support both nationally and internationally, and their stunts seemed to be driven by a desire for publicity.

headline: Vyas demands action against Medha, Roy
article: ahmedabad: reacting sharply to the demonstrations by arundhati roy and medha patkar daring the supreme court to take action, narmada samarthan convenor jay narayan vyas has pleaded for stern action against this group. in a strongly-worded letter addressed to the chief justice of india, vyas has indicated that the demonstration made by arundhati roy and her colleagues openly defying the supreme court's observations and even challenging the authority of the apex court "has now exposed their real face and ideology, removing the mask under which they were covered." castigating this demonstration as a contempt of the supreme court, vyas has further observed that this is not only a defiance and insult of apex court but also a challenge to the constitutionally-appointed authority showing sheer contempt towards the democratic process and the most important institution _ the judiciary. vyas said these are the same people who, till it suits them, would beg before the supreme court for justice, but the moment the situation develops exposing their real intentions they will turn around 180 degrees and go to the extent of daring the apex court. "whatever the intentions, whatever may be the cause, the buck has to stop somewhere," he said. he has appealed to the chief justice that these people, who are out to exploit magnanimity of the supreme court and want to go ahead undeterred with their plans, must be checked. he has requested to the chief justice that such people, who do not care for democratic process or the well-established judicial system in the country, may be restrained from approaching judicial or quasi-judicial authorities as they themselves have shown defiance towards the system of administration of justice. vyas said, "they have already lost their battle in the national and international fora. the popular opinion was turning against them and they are being chased out by the people from even their most safe strongholds. i think now they are resorting to these kind of stunts for the sake of publicity."
summary:
Narmada Samarthan convenor Jay Narayan Vyas strongly condemned the demonstrations led by Arundhati Roy and Medha Patkar, where they challenged the Supreme Court's authority. In a forceful letter to the Chief Justice of India, Vyas argued that these demonstrations had exposed the true face and ideology of the group, removing their figurative mask.

He went on to describe their actions as contempt of the Supreme Court, not only defying and insulting the apex court but also challenging the constitutionally-appointed authority. Vyas criticized the group for seeking justice from the Supreme Court when it suited their interests, only to boldly challenge the court when their true intentions became evident.

Vyas called for measures to restrain these individuals, who seemed determined to exploit the Supreme Court's leniency for their own purposes. He suggested that they should be prevented from approaching judicial or quasi-judicial authorities, given their defiance of the established justice system.

Vyas believed that the group had already lost support both nationally and internationally, and their recent actions were likely driven by a quest for publicity.

headline: Hollywood biggies go begging for theatres
article: In the land of aamir khan and sunny deol, hollywood has a problem. it just doesn't have enough place to unleash its fair-skinned superstars, particularly when the likes of ben affleck, angelina jolie and steven seagal are making an effort to speak in hindi. in other words, the dubbed versions of american blockbusters like pearl harbor, tomb raider and exit wounds are finding it difficult to get theatres in a city squeezed between a couple of bollywood hits and a barrage of forthcoming biggies. "the dubbed versions of these hollywood films constitute 65 per cent of their collections," points sarabjit singh, general manager (india) paramount films, who delayed the release of tomb raider by three weeks to avoid clashing with the glut of new and old releases in theatres. "the fact is that hindi films get preference over dubbed hollywood films. so the only way we can cope with this situation is by spacing out our releases. on the other hand, we also can't delay the release of films for too long because pirated vcds, and even dvds, of the latest hollywood hits are easily available these days." the dubbed hindi version of a hollywood hit is usually released across nine to ten theatres in the city. but pearl harbor has just one theatre in the city running its dubbed version, while exit wounds found seagal speaking hindi in three theatres outside mumbai. "i had no option, but to release pearl harbor in this rush," explains uday singh of columbia tristar. "the point is there are theatres available, but they are not the kinds that excite you. so the only solution to this problem is a couple of multiplexes in the city. because it does mean a loss of revenue for us, particularly in mumbai; for we do get theatres in other parts of the country." while hollywood has been pushed into a corner by bollywood's barrage of releases, it is also finding its biggest blockbusters pitted against each other. so the dinosaurs of jurassic park 3 will fight for its audience with the simians of planet of the apes. and in the weeks to come we'll see tomb raider, kiss of the dragon, swordfish, cats & dogs and evolution.
summary: In the Bollywood-dominated Indian film market, Hollywood faces challenges in securing theater space for dubbed versions of its blockbusters. These dubbed films generate a significant portion of their collections in Hindi, but they compete with a steady stream of Bollywood releases. To cope with this competition, Hollywood studios have started spacing out their releases and are considering the need for multiplexes in the city to accommodate their films. Hollywood blockbusters are also finding themselves in competition with each other, making the battle for audience attention even more challenging. This situation reflects the ongoing clash between Bollywood and Hollywood in the Indian film industry.

headline: Coronavirus | India becomes first country in the world to report over 4 lakh new cases in a single day on April 30, 2021
article: With 4,08,323 new COVID-19 cases recorded until 11 p.m. on April 30, India became the first country in the world to register over 4 lakh infections in a single day. As many as 3,464 new deaths were also reported on the day. Maharashtra reported 62,919 infections, followed by Karnataka (48,296), and Kerala (37,199). Maharashtra also recorded 828 casualties, followed by Delhi (375) and Uttar Pradesh (332). The country has so far reported a total of 1,91,63,488 cases and 2,11,778 deaths.
summary:
As every one knows COVID pandemic is  roaring, On April 30, India became the first country in the world to register over 4 lakh cases in a single day. Currectly 4,08,323 cases registered and 3,464 deaths on that day. According to state wise Maharashtra 62,919 infections, 
Karnataka (48,296) and Kerala (37,199), Maharashtra also recorded 828 casualties, Delhi (375) and Uttar Pradesh (332).India eported a total of 1,91,63,488 cases and 2,11,778 deaths.

headline: Workshop on natural herbal dyes next week
article: bangalore: sanskriti, a non-profit trust promoting indian heritage is organising a workshop at chitra kala parishat on monday 13th and tuesday 14th august 2001 on the techniques of making natural dyes from herbs, roots etc and creating patterns on fabric using the indian bandhini and japanese shiburi techniques. indian bandhini is age-old technique used in rajasthan and gujarat to create beautiful patterns on fabric. shiburi is an ancient japanese technique in which the fabric is folded, stretched, tied in various ways to resist the entry of dyeing in specified areas. creative patterns emerge out and the possible of exploring new patterns are never ending. the workshop is limited to 25 participants on first come first serve basis. enrollment details can he obtained from komala, phone 3465269, email: sanskrti@bgl.vsnl.net.in.
summary: Sanskriti, a non-profit trust promoting Indian heritage, is hosting a two-day workshop at Chitra Kala Parishat in Bangalore on August 13th and 14th, 2001. The workshop focuses on teaching techniques for creating natural dyes from herbs and roots, as well as using Indian Bandhini and Japanese Shiburi methods to create patterns on fabric. Bandhini is an ancient Indian technique for creating patterns in Rajasthan and Gujarat, while Shiburi is a Japanese method involving folding, stretching, and tying fabric to create intricate patterns. The workshop is limited to 25 participants on a first-come, first-served basis, and enrollment details can be obtained by contacting Komala at 3465269 or via email at sanskrti@bgl.vsnl.net.in.

headline: Govt to help improve coffee quality
article: madikeri: the state government will focus on improving quality of coffee and providing the right infrastructure under the tenth five year plan for coping with the low prices which had affected planters. sources said improving coffee-related infrastructure, increasing the rate of replantations and marketing are focus areas in the next plan. coffee board would help growers improve the quality by providing facilities like washing, drying yards, improved machinery and storage, they said. many small growers, numbering 1.4 lakh, have unsuitable drying yards made of slurry plaster. as it absorbs moisture and spoils the beans, coffee board plans to control it by helping them set up tile and cement yards. growers will also be provided with machinery such as pulper washers. in infrastructure, computerisation has been identified as priority to update the database. a computerised network is being planned to obtain inputs from growers on exports and imports, replantations, loans and feedback on coffee board's research and extension projects. as some current plantations have shown susceptibility to pests, the board plans to replant disease-resistant varieties with assistance from its research wing. the coffee board has also sought advice from indian institute of management, ahmedabad, and dristhi, an ngo, to increase the domestic consumption of the beverage.
summary: The state government in Madikeri plans to address the challenges faced by coffee planters in the region, focusing on improving coffee quality and infrastructure during the tenth five-year plan. The plan includes initiatives to enhance coffee-related infrastructure, increase replantation rates, and improve marketing efforts. The Coffee Board will support growers in improving coffee quality by providing facilities like washing, drying yards, upgraded machinery, and storage. Additionally, efforts will be made to computerize and update the database for better data management. Replanting disease-resistant coffee varieties and seeking advice from external organizations are also part of the plan to address issues like pest susceptibility and increase domestic coffee consumption.

headline: YSR Congress’ Dasari Sudha wins by-election to AP’s Badvel assembly seat
article: YSR Congress party candidate Dr Dasari Sudha on Tuesday won the by-election to the Badvel assembly seat in Andhra Pradesh's Kadapa district. She defeated her nearest rival P Suresh of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) with a massive margin of 85,505 votes.
summary: In the recent by-election for the Badvel assembly seat in Andhra Pradesh's Kadapa district, Dr. Dasari Sudha, the candidate from the YSR Congress party, emerged victorious. She secured an impressive victory, defeating her closest competitor, P. Suresh from the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), by a substantial margin of 85,505 votes

headline: JEE Main 2021: Here’s how the cut-off determined
article: The National Testing Agency (NTA) will declare the JEE Main 2021 qualifying cut-off along with the result. The cut-off of JEE Main is the minimum percentile score that candidates need to score in order to qualify for JEE Advanced. Candidates securing the NTA percentile equal to or more than the qualifying cut-off will be eligible to appear for JEE Advanced 2021 for admission into 23 IITs.
summary: The National Testing Agency (NTA) will announce the JEE Main 2021 qualifying cut-off when they release the results. This cut-off represents the minimum percentile score that candidates must achieve to be eligible for the JEE Advanced exam. If a candidate's NTA percentile score is equal to or higher than the qualifying cut-off, they can participate in the JEE Advanced 2021 exam. This exam is crucial for admission into the 23 Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs).

headline: London Diary: We can't have a herd immunity approach to coronavirus in Britain
article: For herd immunity to work, experts say around 60 per cent of the population, some 40 million people, need to catch the virus, Shoppers wearing masks are faced with partially empty shelves at a supermarket in London on March 14, 2020, as consumers worry about product shortages, leading to the stockpiling of household products due to the outbreak of the novel coronavirus COVID-19. Faced with supermarkets being emptied and online shopping overrun due to the COVID-19 pandemic, UK retailers are appealing to consumers to come to their senses and ensure that the country will not run out of food. (AFP).
summary: To achieve herd immunity, experts suggest that around 60% of the population, which amounts to approximately 40 million people, need to contract the virus. However, this approach comes with significant risks and challenges. During the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, there was a surge in panic buying and stockpiling of household items in the UK. This led to partially empty shelves in supermarkets and a strain on online shopping services, as people were concerned about product shortages. Given this situation, UK retailers appealed to the public to act sensibly and avoid excessive stockpiling. They wanted to ensure that there would be enough food and essential products available for everyone in the country. The message was that responsible shopping practices were essential to prevent shortages and ensure that essential supplies remained accessible to all.

headline: From Lucknow to the moon: How Ritu Karidhal took on the Chandrayaan-2 challenge
article: LUCKNOW: Lucknow is getting ready for its own moment of glory on July 15 when the historic Chandrayaan-2 moon mission will be launched under the supervision of India’s rocket woman, Ritu Karidhal Srivastava, who has her roots in the city of Nawabs. Ritu was actively associated with the Mars mission as deputy operations director. Now, as mission director, she is supervising the ambitious Chandrayaan-2 which is scheduled to be launched at 2:51 am on Monday.
summary: Lucknow is gearing up for a significant event on July 15: the launch of the historic Chandrayaan-2 moon mission. This mission is being led by India's accomplished scientist Ritu Karidhal Srivastava, who hails from Lucknow. Ritu previously played a crucial role in the Mars mission as the deputy operations director. Now, she holds the position of mission director and is overseeing the ambitious Chandrayaan-2 project, set to launch at 2:51 am on Monday. This is a moment of pride for the city and the nation as a whole, as they prepare for this remarkable space mission.

headline: Govt 'stands' by 2021 Parliament reply that Sebi was investigating Adani Group
article: As a political row erupted over SEBI telling Supreme Court that it has not been probing the Adani group since 2016, the Finance Ministry on Monday said it stands by its July 2021 written reply in Parliament that had stated that the stock market regulator was investigating some Adani group companies.
summary: A political dispute has arisen following SEBI's statement to the Supreme Court, in which they claim they haven't been investigating the Adani group since 2016. In response, the Finance Ministry reaffirmed its position, stating that it supports the response it provided in July 2021 to Parliament. In that response, they mentioned that the stock market regulator was indeed conducting investigations into certain Adani group companies. This conflicting information has caused a disagreement and raised questions.

headline: 50 Airport Photos That Will Make You Not Want To Board An Airplane Anytime Soon Due To All The Madness
article: Here we have one rare instance on this list of airport madness that just exudes pure bliss. Clearly, the couple is madly in love! This may only be a photo, but it feels like it’s a scene from a romance movie. Not only did this man go to the airport to pick up his sweetheart after a trip, but he also decided to get down on one knee, probably hoping that she’d never leave him like that again. You can see that those around them are almost as excited as the couple themselves. Judging by the look on the girl’s face, we’re guessing she said yes.
summary: Among the many chaotic and stressful moments at airports, there's a rare and heartwarming one. In this instance, it's a scene that radiates pure happiness and love. It's almost like a moment from a romantic movie. A man has come to the airport to welcome his beloved after her trip, and to everyone's surprise, he decided to propose to her right there, likely hoping she'd never have to leave him like that again. The atmosphere around them is filled with excitement and joy, not just for the couple, but for those witnessing this heartfelt moment. Looking at the girl's expression, it's safe to assume that she accepted his proposal, making this a truly special and memorable moment for them both.

headline: Rims Doctors protest against salary cut
article:
RANCHI: The unpaid doctors of Jharkhand's premier medical college and hospital, Rajendra Institute of Medical Sciences (RIMS) have decided to launch a full-fledged agitation to realize their dues. The state government has decided to slash 25% of their salaries paid to them as non-practicing allowance (NPA).
Around 300 junior doctors of RIMS wore black badges to their workplace on Thursday demanding NPA with their salaries. Not just the junior doctors, seniors, too, have not received their salary or NPA for the last two months.
RIMS administration has recently been given annual allotment of funds for the year 2012-13. Last year's allotment was used by the hospital administration to pay salaries and NPA to these doctors.
However, with the latest allotment a directive has been given to the RIMS administration from the state government not to pay NPA from the fund. Following the issuance of the notice junior doctors called upon RIMS director Tulsi Mahto to register their protests.
"The price of petrol has been hiked. The cost of living is too high these days but instead of increasing our salaries, these days but instead of increasing our salaries, the government is slashing it." said a junior doctor, who did not want to be quoted."
RIMS medical superintendent S K Chaudhary said, "The doctors have lodged their protests but they have not skipped work."
According to a rough estimate on Thursday around 2500 patients were attended to by the doctors at RIMS.
Later, the doctors held a meeting at anatomy hall to discuss future strategies.
"The principal secretary has sought 10 days time to resolve the issue"
 When contacted Tulsi Mahto said, "A group of doctors had called on me today. But I will not speak on the issue right now".
Another group of doctors had gheraoed Tulsi Mahto's office on wednesday demanding an explanation on the same issue. Later they had also called upon Jharkhand principal secretary for health K Vidyasagar to address their grievances.
summary: Doctors at Rajendra Institute of Medical Sciences (RIMS) in Jharkhand are upset because the government has cut 25% of their pay, specifically a part called non-practicing allowance (NPA). This means they're not getting their full salaries. About 300 junior doctors wore black badges to work to show their frustration. Even the senior doctors haven't been paid for two months. Last year, the hospital used its funding to pay salaries and NPA, but this year the government said they can't use the money for NPA. The doctors are really unhappy about this because the cost of living is high and petrol prices have gone up. They're asking for their full pay. The RIMS director said they're looking into it, but didn't give more details. Another group of doctors met with the principal secretary for health to talk about their concerns. They're giving the government 10 days to figure things out.

headline: Greenhouse gases reach new record high levels in 2021: UN weather agency
article: The three main greenhouse gases hit record high levels in the atmosphere last year, the UN weather agency said on Wednesday, calling it an ominous sign as war in Ukraine, rising costs of food and fuel, and other worries have elbowed in on longtime concerns about global warming in recent months. More bad news for the planet, the World Meteorological Organisation said in a statement along with its latest annual Greenhouse Gas Bulletin. It's one of several reports released in recent days looking at several aspects of humanity's struggle with climate change in the run up to the UN's latest climate conference, in Sharm el-Sheikh in Egypt.
summary: The UN weather agency has raised an alarming concern: the three major greenhouse gases in our atmosphere reached record-high levels last year. This development is a troubling sign, especially as the world grapples with issues like the conflict in Ukraine, increasing food and fuel costs, and various other pressing concerns that have taken the spotlight away from the ongoing issue of global warming. The World Meteorological Organization, in its annual Greenhouse Gas Bulletin, delivered more concerning news for our planet. This adds to a series of reports released recently, all shedding light on the challenges we face in dealing with climate change. These reports come just before the UN's upcoming climate conference in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt, where the global community will address these critical issues.

headline: World Environment Day 2021: Boost for hospitality! How IHCL, ITC, JW Marriott, Leisure Hotels drive sustainable practices
article: World Environment Day 2021: India’s hospitality industry is challenging not only conventional practices but also the image of sustainability itself in the landscape of its hospitality ecosystem. The drive towards sustainability is what pulls many premium leisure hotels to pave the way for innovative and eco-friendly practices. Financial Express Online reached out to the leading hospitality stakeholders in the country to understand how they are driving the momentum with eco-friendly and sustainable practices across their properties.
summary: On World Environment Day 2021, it's worth noting that India's hospitality industry is making a significant effort to not only change traditional practices but also reshape the concept of sustainability within the hospitality sector. Many high-end leisure hotels are taking the lead in adopting innovative and eco-friendly approaches to promote sustainability. Financial Express Online contacted key players in the hospitality industry in India to gain insights into how they are contributing to this eco-friendly and sustainable momentum within their properties. These efforts mark a positive shift towards more responsible and environmentally friendly practices in the hospitality sector.

headline: IIM-B runs into second Hurdle
article:
BANGALORE: There's a new hurdle the Indian Institute of Management-Bangalore has to clear before going global: the Karnataka government.
With the Union HRD minister Arjun Singh giving the go-ahead for IIMs to set up campuses abroad after amending the Memorandum of Association (MoA), the IIM-B will have to get necessary approvals from the state government to make necessary amendments.
Reason? IIM-B is registered under the Mysore Societies Registered under the Mysore Societies Registration Act XVII of 1960
An amendment in its memorandum can be done only by a general body meeting, which will then have to be approved by the Centre and the respective state government.
..The Centre and the state govt are members of the IIM-B Society.
The Karnataka government had granted 100 acres of land for the IIM-B campus on Bannerghatta Road. Three officials representing various departments of the state government are members of the IIM-B Society. The Bangalore University V-C is also a member of the general body.
As per the existing rules, the IIM-B Board of Governors with the approval of the Centre has to submit a proposition to amend the MoA in a written/ printed form and convene a special general body meeting for the purpose.
Members have to be informed of the meeting at least 21 days before the GBM by registered post.
Once the proposition gets a majority vote, another special general meeting has to be convened by the Board after 30 days from the previous meeting. "Since the state government is part of the Society, its approval is necessary."
Apart from amending the MoA, we will frame our own by-laws so that we don't have to go back to the government for everything," Shyamal Roy, dean (academic), IIM-B, said.
summary: The Indian Institute of Management-Bangalore (IIM-B) wants to expand internationally, but the Karnataka government has created a new obstacle. To make this happen, the IIM-B needs to change some of its rules. However, because it is registered under a specific law in Karnataka, any changes need approval from both the central government and the state government. The Karnataka government has given land for the IIM-B campus, and its officials are part of the decision-making group. This means their agreement is essential. The IIM-B is working on making its own rules, so they don't have to ask the government for permission every time they want to make a change.

headline: The year 2009 was ‘agnipareeksha’ for me, says Yeddyurappa
article: Karnataka Chief Minister B.S. Yeddyurappa on Friday termed the year 2009 his “agnipareeksha” (ordeal by fire) and said he would give priority to bring in changes to fine-tune the State administration. Addressing presspersons here, Mr. Yeddyurappa said, “I will dedicate more attention to improvement of the State administration and the people should feel the change in the year 2010. The whole of 2009 was an ‘agnipareeksha’ for me.”
summary: Karnataka Chief Minister B.S. Yeddyurappa referred to 2009 as his "agnipareeksha" and promised to focus on enhancing the state's administration in 2010. He aimed to bring positive change after a challenging 2009.

headline: Date' with Dabboo!
article: This is an event Bollywood looks forward to every year. Come January, and you know ace photographer Dabboo Ratnani’s going to showcase his immense talent through 12 amazingly shot photographs in his annual calendar. This year was no different and Bollywood’s badshahs and babes were present to congratulate Dabboo, who was in the spotlight that night. Shah Rukh Khan (who flew back from Delhi just for the event) posed in front of his picture; Genelia in front of hers. Hrithik Roshan and Zayed Khan bonded big time; Vidya Balan came in late after having shot a ‘A day in the life of Vidya Balan’ program through the day! AD Singh chatted with Umesh Jivnani, Pradeep Hirani with Narendra Kumar. Aalim Hakim, Hard Kaur, Preeti Jhangiani, Lubna Adams who caught up with Aarti and Kailash Surendranath, Bunty Walia, Sanjay Gupta, Ashish Raheja, Divya Dutta, Nisha Jamvwal, Arjan Bajwa... everyone was there for their date with Dabboo!
summary: Bollywood eagerly anticipates ace photographer Dabboo Ratnani's annual calendar unveiling every January. This year was not an exception as A-list celebrities graced the event to celebrate his talent. Shah Rukh Khan, who flew in from Delhi, posed alongside his portrait, while Genelia did the same. Hrithik Roshan and Zayed Khan enjoyed a strong camaraderie, and Vidya Balan joined after a busy day of filming her program 'A day in the life of Vidya Balan.' The star-studded guest list included AD Singh, Pradeep Hirani, Aalim Hakim, Hard Kaur, Preeti Jhangiani, and many others, all eager to have their moment with Dabboo Ratnani's photography.

headline: Stalemate persists on Vasundhara issue
article: The stand-off between former Rajasthan Chief Minister Vasundhara Raje and the BJP leadership over her being asked to quit as Leader of the Opposition in the State Assembly continued on Saturday even as it appeared that both sides have further hardened their positions. The 60-odd MLAs who returned from Delhi after informing party president Rajnath Singh that they wanted the leadership to retain Ms. Raje as Opposition leader continued to hold consultations among themselves at her Civil Lines residence here. The BJP State leadership, till now tight-lipped on the party directive to Ms. Raje to step down, started speaking out, apparently on instructions from Mr. Singh.
summary: In the above article, there was a stand-off between women named Vasundara Raje, who was a former Chief Miniser of Rajasthan and the BJP leadership. That party's president was Rajnath Singh, the members wanted the leadership to retain her as opposition leader at her Civil Lines residence.

headline: Is Siddharth dating Shruti Haasan?
article: Sorry to start with a cliche like remember Siddharth? But in the case of this actor there’s no choice but to start with that sentence. Siddharth, the South Indian star, who made heads turn in Rang De Basanti(2006) is back in Bollywood with a film titled Striker.But it is not his striking abilities on screen that one is excited about. What we hear is that after dating and reportedly ditching Soha Ali Khan, Siddy boy is now allegedly seeing Shruti Haasan (daughter of Sarika and Kamal Haasan). Well, well two things Siddy doesn't lack is attitude and the aptitude to find himself nice looking girls each time. It is sheer coincidence that he ends up dating women whose names start with the alphabet ‘S’. So sweet na?
summary: Siddharth the South Indian actor who gained recognition with "Rang De Basanti" (2006), returns to Bollywood with "Striker". However, the publicity isn't just about his on-screen talent. Following a reported breakup with Soha Ali Khan, Siddharth is now rumored to be dating Shruti Haasan, daughter of Sarika and Kamal Haasan. Siddharth's knack for charming women with names starting with 'S' is noteworthy, adding an interesting twist to his love life.

headline: Date or place of birth will not be part of UID
article:
BANGALORE: Whatever else the Unique ID might have, it shouldn’t have these — date and place of birth and your native state/district. All children too will get a UID number.
These are among the guidelines laid down by the Demographic Data Standards and Verification Procedure (DDSVP) committee headed by former Central Vigilance Commission chairman N Vittal in its report to the Unique Identification Authority of India (UIDAI). This to ensure demographic data is captured in a standardized manner so that the identity information works across all systems. ‘‘The date/place of birth/ residence and other attributes should not be embedded in the UID number. When state/ district IDs are embedded, the number faces the risk of becoming invalid and misleading the authenticator when people move place to place. It can also lead to profiling or targeting based on region, state or a district from where the person hails. There can be centralized database management systems which can index the records for rapid search and access without having to section data by location or date of birth,’’ the committee said in its report, a copy of which is available with TOI.The Centre set up UIDAI and appointed Infosys co-founder Nandan Nilekani as chairman with a mandate to issue a unique identification number to all Indians. UID for children: The committee said all children will be assigned a number. ‘‘Since children’s fingerprints are not fully formed, during enrolment, details of the parents should be captured to link the child to established UIDs so that either of the parents can be used to authenticate the child.’’ Interestingly, the committee said when the child’s biometrics are well-formed, biometrics will be captured and the child will be de-duplicated to ensure the uniqueness of the child. Leverage mobiles: Given the rapid penetration of mobile phones and landlines across the country and across economic groups, the phone could become an enabling device used to authenticate a person, especially in villages where internet penetration is still low. Introducer concept: Coming to the aid of lakhs of Indians, specially the poor who don’t have any supporting documents to prove their identity, the committee told UIDAI to start an ‘introducer’ system where those Indians with a valid UID can validate these persons.
summary: The Demographic Data Standards and Verification Procedure (DDSVP) committee, led by former Central Vigilance Commission chairman N Vittal, has issued guidelines for the Unique Identification (UID) project in India. The committee recommended that the UID should not include date and place of birth, as this could lead to issues when people move, profiling, or pointing based on their place of origin. It also stressed that children should receive a UID, linking them to their parents initially and capturing their biometrics once fully formed. The use of mobile phones for authentication and the introduction of an 'introducer' system for identity validation were suggested.

headline: SSC, HSC exam dates announced
article: MUMBAI: Maharashtra's board of secondary and higher secondary education has announced dates for SSC (Std X) and HSC (Std XII) exams. The practical and oral exams for the HSC will be held from February 3 to 20, while the theory papers will be conducted between February 23 and March 19. The oral and practical exams for the SSC will be held from February 10 to 26, while the theory papers will be conducted from March 4 to March 19. This is the first year for which students will be tested for two separate levels of mathematics for the SSC. A couple of years ago, the board gave students who were weak in math the option of studying general mathematics—a stepped down version of the regular math curriculum. This is also the first year for which the board will conduct exams in Sindhi, Kannada and Telugu for the SSC. This year, there will be a three-hour paper for geography, which was earlier for two-and-a-half hours. As usual, there will be multiple sets of question papers for the SSC mathematics and English (third language) papers as well as the HSC English paper in a bid to curb cheating. Students will have to score an aggregate of at least 105 marks as the sum total for all three language papers taken together, and at least 25% in each language, to pass the SSC exam. Students will have to score 35% each in the 40-mark project and 60-mark theory paper for environmental science to pass the SSC and HSC.
summary: Maharashtra's board of secondary and higher secondary education has scheduled SSC (Std X) and HSC (Std XII) exams. HSC practical and oral exams are set for February 3-20, with theory papers from February 23 to March 19. SSC practical and oral exams are from February 10-26, with theory papers from March 4 to March 19. For SSC, there will be two levels of mathematics, and exams will be conducted in Sindhi, Kannada, and Telugu. Geography now has a three-hour paper. Passing requirements include specific marks for language papers and environmental science.

headline: Dates for SSC, HSC exam and result announced
article: AHMEDABAD: Gujarat Secondary & Higher Secondary Education Board (GSHSEB) has declared that the examination of science and general streams of SSC and HSC will be conducted on March 4. While the HSC results for science stream will be announced on May 20 and that of the general stream on May 27. And, the SSC results will be announced on June 3rd. "Considering convenience of both students and parents, the dates of results were announced well in advance, so that students can plan their vacations," said a GSHSEB source. The date for Gujarat Common Entrance Test (GUJCET) has been fixed which will be conducted on April 8. This year 8,72,616 students are appearing for SSC and 3,84,850 students for HSC general stream and 75,299 for HSC science streams.
summary: The Gujarat Secondary & Higher Secondary Education Board has scheduled the SSC and HSC science and general stream exams for March 4, with HSC science results on May 20 and general stream results on May 27. SSC results will be announced on June 3. The Gujarat Common Entrance Test (GUJCET) is set for April 8. A total of 8,72,616 students will appear for SSC, 3,84,850 for HSC general stream, and 75,299 for HSC science streams.

headline: SC restrains Maha cops from filing charge sheet against Param Bir Singh
article: The Maharashtra police cannot press charges in criminal cases being investigated against former Mumbai police commissioner Param Bir Singh, the Supreme Court directed on Monday. “Since the petitioner has joined investigations, the investigation can go on but no challan (charge sheet) is to be filed,” an apex court bench said. The Court on November 22 asked Singh, who was in Chandigarh at the time, to cooperate with investigations while granting him protection from arrest. The court continued this protection and posted the matter for further hearing on January 11. The suspended 1988-batch Indian Police Service officer, who faces allegations of running an extortion racket, has alleged a witchhunt and demanded all cases against him to be probed by the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI). “We have nothing to contest in this petition,” solicitor general Tushar Mehta and additional solicitor general Aman Lekhi said, appearing for the CBI.
summary: The Supreme Court has said that the Maharashtra police cannot file charges in criminal cases against former Mumbai police commissioner Param Bir Singh. He's cooperating with investigations, and the court has given him protection from arrest. The court will continue to protect him and will review the case again on January 11. Param Bir Singh, who's accused of running an extortion racket, wants the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) to investigate all the cases against him. The CBI says they have no objections to this.

headline: Railways sets date with petitioner opposing Kashmir-link project
article:
NEW DELHI: Cornered by judicial intervention, the Railway Board has invited a PIL petitioner to make a presentation on the safety risks that have remained despite the apparent improvements decided by it in August in the ambitious project of linking the Kashmir valley with the rest of the country. Following an order passed last month by the Delhi high court to review its decision on the Kashmir-link project, the board asked the counsel for Centre for Public Interest Litigation (CPIL), Prashant Bhushan, to present his viewpoint to it on January 19. The board has been forced to hold this special meeting with Bhushan even after he had, in a letter dated January 8, accused two of its members, Rakesh Chopra and Shri Prakash, of suppressing the safety risks inherent in the “slope skirting alignment” advocated by them. In his PIL, Bhushan also pointed out that Chopra, member engineering, had undone the corrective action initiated by his predecessor S K Vij in 2008 of scrapping the much-touted plan to build the world’s tallest arch bridge on Chenab and thereby paving the way for adopting a straighter and shorter alignment based on the modern technology of tunneling through mountains. Vij’s corrective action was based on the proposal of switching from the slope-skirting alignment to a straighter and shorter alignment as the latter was designed to reduce exposure of the railway line to land-slides in the geologically fragile Himalayan mountains from Katra to Banihal in the Jammu region. Since the focus of the PIL is on the deficiencies of its August decision to retain the slope-skirting alignment, the board will be hard pressed to justify its failure to implement the assurance given by railway minister Mamata Banerjee in her Budget speech two months earlier that the “foremost concern” of the review of the Kashmir-link project would be “the safety of the passengers”.
