White House national security advisor Jake Sullivan said that the US has held back-channel talks with Iran in recent days to warn the country against escalating the conflict in Israel. This comes as Israeli forces prepare an expected ground assault in response to last weekend’s surprise attack by Hamas.
“We have means of communicating privately with Iran, and we have availed ourselves of those means over the past few days to make clear privately that which we have said publicly,” Jake Sullivan said on CBS News’s Face the Nation.
The US couldn’t rule out that Iran might intervene in the conflict, and was monitoring both the possibility of direct involvement by Tehran and proxy activity by Hezbollah across the border with Lebanon, he said after the US announced that it was sending the USS Eisenhower carrier strike group to the Eastern Mediterranean as tensions escalate in the region.
Jake Sullivan said that the US didn’t have specific new intelligence suggesting a greater risk of escalation, but Iran warned that if Israel’s “war crimes and genocide are not halted immediately, the situation could spiral out of control.”
There would be “far-reaching consequences,” Iran’s mission to the United Nations posted on X (formerly Twitter).
The US national security adviser also told CNN that Israeli officials have informed him that water pipes in southern Gaza have been turned back on.
"I have been in touch with my Israeli counterparts just within the last hour who reported to me that they have, in fact, turned the water pipe back on in southern Gaza," he said. Israel had halted the flow of water as part of its siege of Gaza since the war broke out last weekend.
summary: US national security advisor jake sullivan said that the us is monitoring the situation in israel. us had recently held back channel talk with iran warning them about escalating the war in israel. there were no reports of greater risk but iran warned if israel's war crimes continued the situation will spiral out of control.

headline: Top news of the day: Cannot excuse sexual violence against women in Manipur, says SC; India’s key infra sector growth rises to 8.2% in June, and more
article: The Supreme Court on July 31 said the “systemic” and “unprecedented magnitude” of sexual violence committed against women in Manipur amidst ethnic clashes cannot be excused on the ground that crimes happened to women in other parts of the country too. “You cannot excuse what is taking place in Manipur now on the ground that such crimes are happening to several other women as well in other parts of the country,” Chief Justice of India D.Y. Chandrachud, heading a three-judge Bench, observed. The Bench was dealing with an application that there were women in West Bengal, Chhattisgarh, Rajasthan, and Kerala, all of which happened to be non-BJP ruled States, who were victims of crimes and still waiting for justice.
summary: Sexual violence committed against women in manipur cannot be excused on the pretext that crimes happened to women in other parts too, supreme court said on july 31. women in west bengal, chattisgarh, rajasthan and kerela all of which are non bjp ruled states face crimes and are still awaiting justice.

headline: South stars to celebrate 100 years of Cinema
article: To celebrate the centenary of the Indian film industry, the South Indian Film Chamber of Commerce (SIFCC) has come up with a novel plan. Members of the film chambers of the four south Indian states met earlier this week to firm up a plan to collectively celebrate Indian cinema. Talking about this, C Kalyan, president, SIFCC, told BT, “This is going to be a grand affair. We are all fortunate to be present to celebrate such a momentous occasion and we thought that south India should kickstart the celebrations.” Elaborating on the programme, he says, “We are most probably having it between April 26 and 28 in Chennai. The programme will include felicitations of all those who have made a difference in the industry. During the day we will have talks and workshops on filmmaking, while we will have music, dance and other talents showcased in the evenings. The final day will be a gala night, featuring prominent faces from across all industries.” The programme is slated to happen at the Jawaharlal Nehru Indoor Stadium in Chennai, which is currently under renovation. “We plan to approach Tamil Nadu CM J Jayalalithaa to help us get the venue on time. If we do not get it on the desired day, our next option is the Ramoji Rao Film City, Hyderabad. But, since most of the industry and technicians have Chennai roots, we might opt for Chennai,” says Kalyan. Karnataka Film Chamber of Commerce (KFCC) President B Vijayakumar, who was also present at the first meeting, says, “We are very excited about this event. We plan on inviting the President of India as the chief guest and also have all the four south Chief Ministers present. As far as Sandalwood is concerned, we are going to form a committee, which will ensure that we put up a visual treat and also contribute to the other activities.” The industries are looking at having around a week’s time without shoots, so that all members from the various associations can take part whole-heartedly. “We will be discussing with the heads of associations, including Ambareesh, Thara and Rockline Venkatesh to figure out the time all their members can take off for rehearsals and other finer details,” says Vijayakumar. The proposed function will draw the likes of Ambareesh, Rajinikanth, Kamal Haasan, Chiranjeevi, Mammootty and Mohanlal, among others.
summary: The South Indian Film Chamber of Commerce (SIFCC) is planning a grand celebration for the 100th anniversary of the Indian film industry. Representatives from film chambers in the four southern states met to finalize the plan. The event, scheduled for April 26-28 in Chennai, will include workshops on filmmaking during the day and talent showcases in the evenings. The final day will be a gala night with prominent figures from various industries. They aim to host the event at the Jawaharlal Nehru Indoor Stadium in Chennai, and are seeking support from the Tamil Nadu Chief Minister for the venue. If not available, they have a backup plan for Hyderabad. They are also considering a week-long break from shoots to allow everyone to participate. The celebration hopes to involve big names like Ambareesh, Rajinikanth, Kamal Haasan, Chiranjeevi, Mammootty, and Mohanlal.

headline: Nuclear energy needs debate and thought
article:
Following Anna Hazare’s anti-corruption fast, the country was recently witness to another protest fast that took place on its southern fringes. Around a 150 villagers, mostly fisher folk, from a small village in Tamil Nadu called Idinthakarai, went on an 11-day-long fast to protest against the Koodankulam Nuclear Power Plant which is currently under construction in the Tirunelveli district of Tamil Nadu.

Popular opinion has it that the agitation in Koodankulam gained ground following the nuclear disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in Japan earlier this year.

The project had seen local cooperation from the start but a recent mandatory safety drill appears to have unleashed fears that something must be amiss or could go wrong later. With local elections around the corner, there is the possibility that this unnecessary sense of alarm has been produced as a result of competitive politics.

The protest against the Koodankulam Nuclear Plant is being spearheaded by a group of activists called People’s Movement against Atomic Power. The project was stepped up on August 15 after the village sabha at Idinthakarai resolved that the plant should not be commissioned even if it had been completed. Fishermen of several coastal villages in the area had also come out strongly against the nuclear power plant, saying it posed a danger to their lives and livelihood.

Protesters withdrew their 11day-long fast only after Tamil Nadu Chief Minister J Jayalalithaa assured them that she would pass a resolution in the Cabinet and take up the matter with Prime Minister Manmohan Singh. While Ms Jayalalithaa seems to have taken a strong stand against setting up the Russian nuclear reactors along the coastal belt in Koodankulam, the fact remains that the first of the two 1,000 MW reactors are already entering their final stages of construction. The project envisages building two 1,000 MW VVER type Russian reactors by the Nuclear Power Corporation.

With regards to safety concerns at the plant, especially in the wake of recent Fukushima disaster, the project’s Site Director, Mr PM Kasinath Balaji, has often pointed to the five-tier safety system of the project. According to Mr Balaji, the buildings that house the reactor and its auxiliary equipment, reactor safety systems, safety diesel generators, the control room and other power generating equipment have all been designed to operate safely under seismic activity. Though the project is located in a Very low Seismic Category Zone2, it has nonetheless been designed to withstand geological turmoil such as a tsunami or an earthquake. Moreover, the former chief of the Atomic Energy Commission has also assured the people that The Atomic Energy Department, the Nuclear Power Corporation of India ltd and the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board have all done extensive checks and they all agree that the circumstances that led to the accident at Fukushima are not at all likely to happen in Koodankulam.
summary: Koodankulam Nuclear Plant is facing protest recently after a safety measure drill by fisher folk of village Idinthakarai. as elections are round the corner it seems this was raised as means to disrupt it. the protest was called off after tamil Nadu Chief Minister J Jayalalithaa assured to take this matter to prime minister manmohan singh and pass a resolution in cabinat.

headline: 2018 turned out to be year of glory for sports other than cricket in India. From record-breaking performances in the Gold Coast Commonwealth Games, to achieving the highest ever medal tally in the Asian Games — India saw the rise and rise of struggling and unsung athletes in both individual and team sports, perhaps paving the way for a commensurate haul in the 2020 Olympics. Shooting stands out as the biggest hunting ground in the two big sporting events of the year, where apart from the experienced Hina Sidhu and Jitu Rai, the teenage trio of Manu Bhaker, Saurabh Chaudhary and Anish Bhanwala emerged as the ones to be looked out for in the future. Their sensational triumph at such a tender age was the signage of the treasure for the future. Not just in shooting, but in athletics, too, young unheard of guns, like Hima Das, Neeraj Chopra and Swapna Barman, emerged as the delightful surprise packages. The biggest positive with all these young champions, who set the track on fire for the first time, is the fact that all these are just beginners in their respective sports and have a lot more to give in the coming years. In second most popular sport in the country after cricket, PV Sindhu failed to break the jinx of winning titles throughout the year but the Olympic Silver medallist finally in the last and the most important tourney of the season, the BWF World Tour Finals, broke all barriers to become the first Indian to even win the posh year-ender. In the process, she also surpassed the supposedly invincible Tai Tzu Ying.
article: 2018 turned out to be year of glory for sports other than cricket in India. From record-breaking performances in the Gold Coast Commonwealth Games, to achieving the highest ever medal tally in the Asian Games — India saw the rise and rise of struggling and unsung athletes in both individual and team sports, perhaps paving the way for a commensurate haul in the 2020 Olympics. Shooting stands out as the biggest hunting ground in the two big sporting events of the year, where apart from the experienced Hina Sidhu and Jitu Rai, the teenage trio of Manu Bhaker, Saurabh Chaudhary and Anish Bhanwala emerged as the ones to be looked out for in the future. Their sensational triumph at such a tender age was the signage of the treasure for the future. Not just in shooting, but in athletics, too, young unheard of guns, like Hima Das, Neeraj Chopra and Swapna Barman, emerged as the delightful surprise packages. The biggest positive with all these young champions, who set the track on fire for the first time, is the fact that all these are just beginners in their respective sports and have a lot more to give in the coming years. In second most popular sport in the country after cricket, PV Sindhu failed to break the jinx of winning titles throughout the year but the Olympic Silver medallist finally in the last and the most important tourney of the season, the BWF World Tour Finals, broke all barriers to become the first Indian to even win the posh year-ender. In the process, she also surpassed the supposedly invincible Tai Tzu Ying.
summary: India saw a tremendous progress in sports in 2018  with amazing performance in asian games, gold coast commonwealth games. pv sindhu became the first indian to win the posh year ender in BWF world tour final. there were also surprises in the from of neeraj chopra, hima das, swapna barman in unheard sports by their medal winning performance.

headline: PM's Japan Visit to take ties to new level
article:
TOKYO: The Prime Minister Manmohan Singh said his four-day visit to Japan would elevate Indo-Japan ties to "a qualitatively new level" since the two countries "increasingly find their long-term political, economic and strategic interests are converging."%0D%0AThe corridor project will go a long way in assuaging Japanese concerns about lack of proper infrastructure in India, coupled with bureaucratic delays, lack of tax incentives, rigid labour laws and the like.
Though the bilateral trade with Japan stood at an extremely modest $6-billion figure in 2005-2006, India hopes for a quantum jump in the years ahead, both in terms of boosting bilateral trade as well as Japanese FDI into India.
Towards this end, the PM and his counterpart Shinzo Abe will discuss a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) or an Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) between the two countries.
Kamal Nath and Akira Amari decided that the first meeting of the negotiating group on signing the EPA will be held very soon to cover trade in goods and services, issues concerning investment promotion and intellectual property rights.
"Both the PMs feel economic cooperation is a strategic objective," said principal secretary to the PM, T K A Nair.
There is, of course, a big strategic content to the visit. The PM said he would discuss with Abe "ways to reinforce the strategic focus in our global partnership."
summary: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh's visit to Japan is set to bring India and Japan even closer, as their long-term interests align. They are working on a project to address Japan's concerns about India's infrastructure and bureaucratic delays. Although trade between the two countries was relatively small in the past, India hopes for a big increase in the future, aiming to boost trade and attract more Japanese investment. The leaders will talk about a partnership agreement to strengthen economic cooperation. They also plan to discuss strategic matters to enhance their global partnership.

headline: US, China to sign ‘phase 1’ trade deal on 15 January
article:
Apartial new US-China trade agreement will be signed on 15 January, US President Donald Trump said Tuesday, announcing that he will also then travel to China for continued talks.

“I will be signing our very large and comprehensive Phase One Trade Deal with China on January 15,” Trump tweeted moments before Wall Street was due to open. Trump said he would then travel to Beijing to continue negotiations “at a later date.”

The two sides earlier this month announced a “Phase One” deal in their nearly two-year trade confrontation, with Washington cancelling and reducing some tariffs in exchange for Chinese pledges to increase purchases of US exports and adopt trade reforms.

The text of the agreement has not yet been made public pending legal and translation reviews, US officials say, and details remain scant.

US and Chinese officials said the agreement includes protections for intellectual property, food and farm goods, financial services and foreign exchange, and a provision for dispute resolution.
summary: A partial new trade agreement between the United States and China, referred to as "Phase One," is set to be signed on January 15, according to US President Donald Trump. Trump also mentioned his intention to travel to China for further negotiations at a later date. This deal comes after nearly two years of trade tensions between the two countries and involves concessions such as the reduction and cancellation of some tariffs by the US in exchange for China's commitments to increase purchases of US exports and implement trade reforms. The details of the agreement have not yet been released to the public, as they are undergoing legal and translation reviews. However, it is known to address issues related to intellectual property, food and agriculture products, financial services, foreign exchange, and dispute resolution.

headline: Woke millennials and money, the two indeed meet
article:
Millennials form about 47% of India’s working population, making them the largest demographic group in the country. Mint takes a look at how millennials can strike a balance between spending and saving and make the most of their money.
Should you be saving or splurging?

It could irk you when elders say that you need not spend thousands on that foreign holiday or the new iPhone. Millennials and the younger Gen Z are often criticized for spending on things and experiences the previous generations kept away from. However, what gets ignored is that, over time, lifestyles have evolved. Still, does this mean you blow all your money to achieve that perfect Instagram-worthy click? The answer is to spend but only after you have saved for the things that you would certainly need later. You could begin by saving as little as 15-20% of your monthly take-home pay.
Is it ever too late to start investing?

If you’ve just started working, you may feel you have several years ahead of you and investing doesn’t have to start immediately. However, what you should understand is that the earlier you start investing, the better your returns will be. For example, you start investing ₹2,000 every month for the next 25 years. The final value of your investment would be around ₹20 lakh, assuming an 8% annual return. Besides, your investments will only increase as your income goes up, adding to the total pie of investments and also giving that much more scope for compounding to work its magic.
Are credit cards and easy loans a good option?

As there’s so much to indulge in, you could fall short of money. Swiping your credit card could mitigate that situation. As long as you are disciplined and are repaying the outstanding amount on time, using a credit card can help you build a credit score. Payday loans, on the other hand, come at a high interest rate and can trap you in debt.
Is debt a sign of confidence?

Access to credit cards and loans could help boost your financial confidence and make it easier for you to spend. You may take some loans expecting a salary hike or an awaited bonus. The problem arises when the money does not come in. Such fears are more justified at times when the economic outlook is grim as organizations are not liberal with salary hikes or bonuses in such times. Studies have found that while debt gives a boost and sense of self-confidence to people in the 18-27 age group, the feeling fades as people enter their 30s.
How should you strike a balance?

You could be the “cool” one among your peers with your fancy gadgets and branded clothes. But if you are fuelling these expenses through loans, you are not really being “cool”. Getting habituated to credit can land you in a debt trap and you may then have to give up the façade you’ve built. You should instead secure your future while enjoying the small pleasures of life. Financial planners suggest the 30:30:40 rule: Direct 30% of your income towards expenses, 30% towards EMIs and 40% into the savings kitty.
summary:
This article discusses financial considerations for millennials in India, who make up a significant portion of the country's workforce. It emphasizes the importance of finding a balance between spending and saving. Key points covered in the article include:

Balancing Spending and Saving: Millennials are often criticized for their spending habits, but it's important to spend after saving for future needs. The article suggests saving at least 15-20% of your monthly income.

Early Investing: Starting to invest early is crucial for better returns. The article highlights the power of compounding and how even small investments over time can grow significantly.

Credit Cards and Loans: While credit cards can be useful when used responsibly, payday loans with high-interest rates can lead to debt traps. Responsible use of credit can also help build a good credit score.

Debt and Confidence: Access to credit can boost financial confidence, but over-reliance on loans can become problematic, especially if salary hikes or bonuses don't materialize as expected. This confidence tends to fade as people enter their 30s.

Balancing Expenses: Financial planners recommend the 30:30:40 rule, which allocates 30% of income to expenses, 30% to EMIs (loan repayments), and 40% into savings.

The article provides practical advice for millennials to manage their finances and secure their future while enjoying the present.

headline: A big infra push
article:
The government is betting big on infrastructure development to achieve India’s $5-trillion economy goal by 2024-25. On Tuesday, finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman unveiled a ₹102 trillion infrastructure spending plan for the next five years. The Centre, states, and the private sector will make these investments, though it was unclear how such a huge sum would be financed.

Such projects can sometimes take decades to turn profitable, so banks are often wary of lending if they fear their own short-term funding will not cover the gestation period. An asset-liability mismatch is risky. The public-private partnership finance model has sought to provide a more workable solution, though its success, too, has been chequered. Land acquisition delays and weak enforcement of contracts have also served to dissuade private participation. The scope of the challenge can be gauged from India’s recent infrastructure development record. Despite all the attention, India managed to spend ₹51 trillion on it over the past six years. To double that figure in one less year would require major moves to ease the path. Still, given the resolve, it could be achieved.
summary: The Indian government is making a substantial push for infrastructure development to reach its goal of a $5-trillion economy by 2024-25. Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced a ₹102 trillion infrastructure spending plan for the next five years, involving investments from the government, states, and the private sector. However, it remains unclear how such a significant sum will be financed.

headline: Trump hopes his holiday gift from Kim is ‘a vase’
article:
President Donald Trump said he hoped that his Christmas present from Kim Jong Un “is a vase”—hours after the North Korean leader pledged to show off a “new strategic weapon”.

“I think he is a man of his word,” Trump said in New Year’s Eve remarks at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida. US officials have called on Kim to live up to his denuclearization pledges to Trump.

Kim told a gathering of party officials in Pyongyang that US actions left him no choice but to reconsider commitments that underpinned three unprecedented meetings with Trump over the past 18 months, the state-run Korean Central News Agency said Wednesday.

Kim called for “shocking actual action” to make the US “pay for the pains” suffered by North Korea under the Washington-led sanctions regime, KCNA said.

North Korea had threatened that it would use the end-of-year holiday season to deliver a “Christmas gift” to the US after demanding Washington make additional concessions as part of long-stalled nuclear talks between the two sides. BLOOMBERG
summary:
President Donald Trump expressed his hope for a Christmas gift from Kim Jong Un, North Korea's leader, to be "a vase" in response to Kim's earlier pledge to showcase a "new strategic weapon." Trump made these remarks during New Year's Eve celebrations at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida. U.S. officials have been urging Kim to fulfill his promises regarding denuclearization.

Kim Jong Un had recently informed North Korean party officials in Pyongyang that U.S. actions had left him with no choice but to reconsider commitments made during three unprecedented meetings with President Trump over the past 18 months. Kim called for "shocking actual action" to make the U.S. "pay for the pains" North Korea has experienced under Washington-led sanctions.

North Korea had previously issued threats of delivering a "Christmas gift" to the U.S. during the end-of-year holiday season, demanding additional concessions as part of the stalled nuclear negotiations between the two countries.

headline: RBI’s Operation Twist may boost lending, growth
article:
Recently, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) decided to undertake its own version of Operation Twist to bring down 10-year yields of government securities (G-Secs) and drive monetary transmission. Mint explores this move and its impact on G-Sec yields.
Why is Operation Twist so important?

Operation Twist is a move in which a central bank decides to simultaneously buy long-dated securities while selling short-term securities. The objective behind such an operation is management of the yield curve. Other central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, have used similar measures. This is the first time RBI has undertaken such an unconventional policy measure with the aim of flattening the yield curve by lowering longer rates to boost lending and growth. On Monday, RBI undertook its second round of open market operations (OMOs), the first round of which was undertaken on 23 October.
Did RBI buy, sell bonds of the same amounts?

A conventional Operation Twist involves a central bank buying and selling securities of the same amounts. The purchase of securities pushes down the yields of long-dated securities, while the sale of short-term bonds drives up their yield. This transaction is undertaken as it effectively reduces the term premia. But in the case of RBI’s recent move, on 23 October, the central bank bought a net of ₹10,000 crore of 10-year bonds and sold one-year bonds of ₹6,825 crore. On 30 December, RBI again bought 10-year bonds worth ₹10,000 crore while selling one-year bonds worth ₹8,501 crore.
So did the move have an impact on bond yields?

The recent Operation Twist impacted bond yields that had shot up to 6.705% on 18 December. The move was announced on 19 December 2019 and yields moderated to 6.501% on 1 January 2020. Ending uncertainty on fiscal deficit numbers for 2019-20 and 2020-21 and a credible long-term fiscal consolidation path will help moderate bond yields.
Why did 10-year yields rise after 30 Dec?

In the past, RBI had ruled out its desire to get into yield curve management. But by undertaking Operation Twist, it has provided strong signals to markets that could be well on the cards. Despite this, the second Operation Twist on 30 December didn’t pare yields as investors are jittery due to concerns regarding the FY20 fiscal deficit. RBI also released the calendar for state borrowings of ₹2 trillion for the Q4 FY20. Operation Twist is likely to have subdued the impact of these developments on the yield curve.
Can we expect more such operations?

Over the last few months there has been a call for OMOs to drive monetary transmission. More such operations are possible as RBI tries to improve transmission and the monetary policy panel continues with an accommodative stand. A countercyclical fiscal policy is warranted due to the growth slowdown and is factored in by investors. Thus, by revising deficit targets and creating a credible medium-term consolidation path, the Centre can send bond markets a positive signal, which would supplement RBI’s Operation Twist.
summary:
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) recently implemented its version of Operation Twist, which involves buying long-dated securities while selling short-term securities. Here's an overview of this move and its impact on government security (G-Sec) yields:

Importance of Operation Twist: Operation Twist is a central bank's strategy to manage the yield curve by buying long-term securities and selling short-term ones. The primary goal is to influence interest rates at different maturities. Other central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, have used similar measures. This was the first time the RBI adopted this unconventional policy measure to flatten the yield curve by reducing longer-term rates, aiming to boost lending and economic growth.

RBI's Transaction Details: The RBI's recent move involved buying ₹10,000 crore worth of 10-year bonds while selling ₹8,501 crore of one-year bonds on December 30th. This approach was intended to reduce term premia, affecting different bond maturities.

Impact on Bond Yields: The recent Operation Twist had a noticeable impact on bond yields, which had risen to 6.705% on December 18. After the move was announced on December 19, 2019, yields dropped to 6.501% on January 1, 2020. The stabilization of bond yields was attributed to ending uncertainty about fiscal deficit figures and establishing a credible long-term fiscal consolidation plan.

Yield Curve Management Signals: While RBI had previously ruled out direct involvement in yield curve management, the Operation Twist signaled a potential shift in its stance. However, the second round of Operation Twist on December 30th didn't have as much effect on yields due to investor concerns about the fiscal deficit for the fiscal year 2019-20. RBI's announcement of state borrowings worth ₹2 trillion for Q4 FY20 also played a role in shaping market sentiment.

Expectation of More Operations: In light of the need to improve monetary transmission, more operations like Operation Twist are expected in the future. The RBI aims to enhance transmission while maintaining an accommodative monetary policy stance. A counter-cyclical fiscal policy is seen as necessary due to economic growth slowdown, and by addressing deficit targets and establishing a credible medium-term consolidation plan, the government can send positive signals to bond markets, complementing the RBI's Operation Twist efforts.

Operation Twist is a tool used by central banks to influence the yield curve and interest rates to stimulate economic activity and lending.

headline: Airfare anxiety
article:
Civil aviation minister Hardeep Singh Puri appears to have pinned the blame for airlines’ losses on “predatory pricing”. They could be headed the telecom way, he warned, if they keep selling tickets below operational costs. Spare a thought for his concerns. Profits are elusive and airfares have failed to keep up with inflation. A virtual cap has been placed on prices by the intensity of competition. As India’s biggest carrier is the state-owned Indian Railways, the government also has reason to worry that people can fly between, say, Mumbai and Delhi, for only a little more money than the cost of an express-service train ticket.

But are airfares in India predatory? The dynamic pricing models of airlines often do seem to offer tickets too cheap to cover expenses. Yet, it isn’t easy to discern whether the aim of this is to wage a war of attrition against rivals. Aviation, after all, is a peculiar market. This is because air carriers offer a perishable product: A seat that goes empty cannot be sold later. If demand is not robust, it would make sense for airlines to sell some seats at passenger-luring discounts just to fill the aircraft. Getting some revenue on these seats is better than none.
summary: The Civil Aviation Minister of India, Hardeep Singh Puri, has expressed concerns about airlines incurring losses due to what he calls "predatory pricing." He warns that if airlines continue to sell tickets below operational costs, they could face a situation similar to the telecom industry. Airfares in India have struggled to keep up with inflation, and fierce competition has led to relatively low ticket prices. The government is also worried about this because the state-owned Indian Railways is the country's largest carrier, and air travel is becoming a cheaper alternative to train journeys on some routes.

headline: AI system beats human breast cancer diagnosis
article:
A computer programme can identify breast cancer from routine scans with greater accuracy than human experts, researchers said in what they hoped could prove a breakthrough in the fight against the global killer.

In Britain, women over 50 are advised to get a mammogram every three years, the results of which are analysed by two independent experts.

But interpreting the scans leaves room for error, and a small percentage of all mammograms either return a false positive (misdiagnosing a healthy patient as having cancer), or false negative (missing the disease as it spreads).

Now researchers at Google Health have trained an artificial intelligence (AI) model to detect cancer in breast scans from thousands of women in Britain and the US.

The team found that their AI model could predict breast cancer from the scans with a similar accuracy level to expert radiographers.

The team also said that further research was needed, but they hoped that the technology could one day act as a “second opinion” for cancer diagnoses.
summary:
Researchers at Google Health have developed an artificial intelligence (AI) model that can identify breast cancer in routine scans with remarkable accuracy, potentially offering a significant breakthrough in cancer diagnosis. In the UK, women over 50 receive mammograms every three years, and the results are typically reviewed by two independent experts. However, human interpretation of these scans can still lead to errors, resulting in false positives or false negatives.

Google Health's AI model has been trained on thousands of breast scans from women in the UK and the US, and it has demonstrated the ability to predict breast cancer with a level of accuracy similar to that of expert radiographers. While further research is required, the technology has the potential to serve as a valuable "second opinion" in the diagnosis of cancer.

headline: Success of facial recognition tech depends on data
article:
Facial recognition software is now an integral part of policing, globally. Last month, the police used its automated facial recognition system (AFRS) to screen crowds at Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s rally on the citizenship law in Delhi. Mint analyses its features and scope.
What is the purpose of AFRS software?

AFRS is a software that recognizes, records and matches faces against various government databases from photos and videos taken from public and private sources. Its purpose is to find missing children, who may be recorded on CCTV; track criminals across a country; and in the case of Modi’s rally, recognize people who were likely to raise protest slogans at the rally, based on footage recorded from earlier protests. According to reports, people at Delhi’s Ramlila Maidan had to pass through a metal detector, during which a camera captured a photo of their faces and scanned it against a database in a matter of seconds.
How does the software work?

The police’s AFRS is different from the facial recognition systems used on smartphones. The latter is based on the ISO 19794-5 standard meant for consumer biometrics; the police’s software is more “restrictive”, as per the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) document seeking proposals for the system. It measures facial features and uses the measure-ments to create a “template” to be matched against others, says an American Bar Association study. Law enforcement’s software is meant to work in various light conditions; detect make-up, plastic surgery or ageing; and work against sketches of subjects.
Can facial recognition technology be beaten?

A review of the London Metropolitan Police’s facial recognition system by academics from the University of Essex in July 2019 showed that the system had erred in 81% of the cases. However, law enforcement bodies worldwide have adopted the system, although there are enough reports for and against the software.
Which databases does AFRS have access to?

The NCRB document says AFRS should be able to check against various databases. Besides the criminal database, it mentions the passport database; the Aadhaar database that includes your photo may be used too. It mentions the Immigration, Visa and Foreigners’ Registration Tracking database, the ministry of women and child development’s Khoya-Paya and the National Automated Fingerprint Identification System. It can match a photo against many and compare one photo with another. The more the data, the better is the output.
What is the scope of India’s AFRS?

NCRB’s proposal clearly states that while a centralized web application will be hosted in the crime record bureau’s data centre in Delhi, it will be made available to “all police stations of the country”. That means AFRS certainly stretches on a national scale. Furthermore, Delhi Police also required the software to work on Android, iOS and Windows platforms. “NCRB has already proposed the provision of mobile data terminals to each police station,” states the proposal document.
summary:
Automated Facial Recognition Software (AFRS) has become an integral part of policing, with the potential to serve various purposes. Here are the key points regarding AFRS:

Purpose of AFRS: AFRS is software designed to recognize, record, and match faces from photos and videos against government databases. Its purposes include finding missing children captured on CCTV, tracking criminals across a country, and identifying individuals based on previous protests or events, such as Prime Minister Narendra Modi's rally in Delhi.

How AFRS Works: AFRS used by law enforcement differs from facial recognition systems on smartphones. It measures facial features to create a template for matching faces. This technology can work in various lighting conditions, detect makeup, plastic surgery, aging, and even sketches of subjects.

Effectiveness and Limitations: While AFRS technology is being adopted globally by law enforcement agencies, its accuracy can vary. An academic review of London's Metropolitan Police's facial recognition system found errors in 81% of cases, highlighting its limitations.

Access to Databases: AFRS has access to various databases, including criminal, passport, Aadhaar (which includes photos), Immigration, Visa, Foreigners' Registration Tracking, Khoya-Paya (a child tracking system), and the National Automated Fingerprint Identification System. The more data available, the more accurate the system's output.

Scope in India: India's AFRS initiative aims for a centralized web application hosted at the National Crime Records Bureau's data center in Delhi. It will be made available to all police stations in the country, demonstrating its national scale. The software is also expected to work on multiple platforms, including Android, iOS, and Windows, with the provision of mobile data terminals to police stations.

AFRS technology has the potential to assist law enforcement in various aspects but also raises concerns regarding privacy, accuracy, and ethical use.

headline: Tata vs Mistry
article:
As expected, the Tata Group has moved India’s apex court against the National Companies Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) ruling, which deemed Cyrus Mistry’s 2016 ouster as Tata Sons executive chairman illegal and nixed its conversion from a publicly-held firm to a private one. The case pivots on complex questions of majority versus minority shareholder rights. Ratan Tata controls the Tata Trusts, which own nearly two-thirds of Tata Sons’ equity, while the Mistry family owns about 18.4%. Majority control is almost axiomatic in business, and so Tata seems to have had the authority to oust a key manager. But, was Mistry one? This could be open to interpretation.

Controversy also erupted over whether the NCLAT could rule on a minority oppression case if Tata Sons wasn’t going bust. Even more hair has been split over its switch from public to private. Instead of getting the Centre’s approval, the group reportedly used a circular that only needed the Registrar of Companies’ nod. What drew suspicion to the move’s motive was that it could have granted Tata a handle on Mistry’s shares, a lever that wasn’t used. But still, such a vulnerability can’t be overlooked, can it?

© 2019 All Rights Reserved. Powered by Summit
summary: The Tata Group has taken its legal battle against the National Companies Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) ruling to India's highest court. The NCLAT had previously declared Cyrus Mistry's removal as Tata Sons executive chairman in 2016 as illegal and invalidated the company's conversion from a publicly-held firm to a private one. The case revolves around complex questions regarding majority shareholder rights versus minority shareholder rights. Ratan Tata, who controls the Tata Trusts, owns nearly two-thirds of Tata Sons' equity, while the Mistry family holds about 18.4%. While majority control is a common principle in business, the argument centers on whether Mistry was considered a key manager, which is open to interpretation.

headline: Australia’s ‘insurance’ koala population halved
article:
At least half of Australia’s only disease-free koala population, a key “insurance” for the species’ future, is feared dead with more badly hurt after bushfires swept through an island sanctuary, rescuers said Sunday.

Kangaroo Island, a popular nature-based tourist attraction off the coast of South Australia state, is home to many wild populations of native animals including the much-loved koala, where the population was estimated at 50,000.

Massive bushfires have flared up in the vast country’s southeast in a months-long crisis, killing nearly half a billion native animals in New South Wales state alone, scientists estimate.

Conditions have been particularly severe in recent days, with an ongoing blaze on Kangaroo Island spreading rapidly and razing 170,000 hectares—one-third of the island—on Friday. “Over 50% (of the population) has been lost,” Sam Mitchell of Kangaroo Island Wildlife Park, which is raising funds to care for the injured koalas, told AFP.

“Injuries are extreme. Others have been left with no habitat to go back to, so starvation will be an issue in coming weeks.”

© 2019 All Rights Reserved. Powered by Summit
summary: Australia's only disease-free koala population, which was considered a crucial "insurance" for the species' future, has been severely impacted by bushfires on Kangaroo Island. This popular nature-based tourist destination off the coast of South Australia is home to a significant koala population, estimated at 50,000. However, massive bushfires have been devastating the country's southeast for several months, resulting in the estimated loss of nearly half a billion native animals in New South Wales alone.

headline: The govt is likely to find it hard to trim fiscal deficit
article:
The budgeted fiscal deficit for 2019-20 stands at ₹7.04 trillion. However, the fiscal deficit for the period April-November is higher than this and stands at ₹8.08 trillion. Mint takes a look at the options before the government to reduce the fiscal deficit.Why has the fiscal deficit crossed ₹8 tn?

The fiscal deficit of ₹8.08 trillion for April-November is nearly 15% more than the budgeted fiscal deficit for the year, with data for four months yet to be available. Fiscal deficit basically has two entries: the total expenditure of the government and its total earnings. The total expenditure during the first eight months of the fiscal is ₹18.20 trillion. This is a little over 65% of the expenditure that the government plans to make during the year. Hence, things are all right on the expenditure front. The problems are on the earnings front, in particular the tax revenues that the government had hoped to earn during this fiscal.hat’s wrong with the tax revenue growth?

The gross tax revenue collected by the government during the first eight months of the fiscal was ₹11.74 trillion, around 0.8% higher than during the same period last year. Hence. tax collections have been largely flat this year. The interesting thing is that the gross tax revenue needs to grow 18.3% from last year’s collections for the government to earn what it has projected in the budget. Finance ministry bureaucrats were not expecting the economy and tax collections to slow down as much as they have. The economy grew by a little over 7% in the first half of this fiscal. The growth in tax collections hasn’t matched that.How do things look for the remaining part of this fiscal?

The gross tax revenue that the government had hoped to earn this fiscal is ₹24.61 trillion. It has barely earned around 48% of this in the first eight months of the fiscal. It is highly unlikely for the government to earn the remaining 52% between December 2019 and March 2020. This means there is a large hole in its budget for the current fiscal.Can disinvestment solve this problem?

The disinvestment of public sector enterprises was supposed to bring in ₹1.05 trillion this fiscal. Until November, only ₹18,099 crore or 17% of the projected amount had been earned. Media reports seem to suggest major disinvestments that the government has planned won’t go through this year. That basically leaves the government with two ways of trimming the fiscal deficit: cutting down on expenditure or not showing it. Reducing expenditure when government spending is driving growth would be a bad idea.
What does it mean not to show expenditure?

Over the years, the government hasn’t paid the food subsidy dues of the Food Corporation of India (FCI) on time. It can try this trick this time as well. Given that the government works on cash accounting, when it decides not to pay for an expenditure it doesn’t show up in the books of the government. Of course, FCI has to borrow this money to keep functioning. Banks lend to FCI mainly because they believe they are lending to the government.

Vivek Kaul is an economist and the author of the Easy Money trilogy.
summary:
India's fiscal deficit for the period of April to November has surpassed the budgeted amount, standing at ₹8.08 trillion, which is nearly 15% higher than the budgeted fiscal deficit for the entire fiscal year. The fiscal deficit is affected by both total government expenditures and earnings, and while expenditures are within expectations, the issue lies with tax revenues.

Tax collections have remained largely flat this fiscal year, with gross tax revenue growing only 0.8% compared to the same period in the previous year. However, the government had anticipated an 18.3% growth in gross tax revenue to meet its budgeted projections. The gap between actual revenue and budgeted revenue poses a significant challenge for the government in terms of meeting its fiscal deficit targets for the year.

The government's target for gross tax revenue for the fiscal year is ₹24.61 trillion, and it has only collected around 48% of this amount during the first eight months. The government is unlikely to bridge this revenue gap by the end of the fiscal year, making it difficult to meet its fiscal deficit goals.

One potential solution for reducing the fiscal deficit is disinvestment, which was expected to bring in ₹1.05 trillion this fiscal year. However, disinvestment progress has been slow, with only 17% of the projected amount earned by November. Media reports suggest that major disinvestments planned by the government may not materialize as expected, further complicating the fiscal situation.

To address the deficit issue, the government might have to consider either cutting down on expenditure, which could negatively impact growth, or adopting strategies like delaying payments for expenditures, which would not be reflected in the government's books but would require borrowing by institutions like the Food Corporation of India to meet their obligations.

headline: A twist at threat
article:
Just as it seemed that the Reserve Bank of India’s “operation twist”, by which it buys long-dated bonds and sells short-tenure ones, was helping lower interest rates on long loans to aid an economic recovery, fresh uncertainty has struck. Iran vowed revenge against the US for killing one of its top commanders last week. If geopolitical tensions escalate, oil prices could zoom and throw the country’s finances into disarray. We import over three-quarters of the stuff.

Indian exports have been stagnant, so a sharp rise in our import bill would likely widen the gap between what we spend and what we earn in dollars. Retail fuel prices could be kept stable if levies are slashed, but that would strain the governments’ already-stretched fiscal deficit. Increased debt taken on by the Centre tends to push up market rates of interest. Alternatively, if fuel prices are raised, inflation control may require the central bank to tighten money availability, which would have the same adverse effect. The country has been fortunate that oil has not been terribly volatile over the past half decade, allowing the government to overtax fuel. Let’s prepare for new complexities.

© 2019 All Rights Reserved. Powered by Summit
summary:
India's financial situation, which had shown signs of improvement with the Reserve Bank of India's "operation twist" aimed at lowering interest rates on long-term loans, faces new uncertainties due to geopolitical tensions. Following Iran's vow to seek revenge against the US for the killing of a top commander, oil prices may escalate, impacting India's finances significantly as it imports over three-quarters of its oil.

India's exports have been stagnant, and a sharp increase in the country's import bill could widen the trade deficit, putting pressure on the fiscal deficit. Lowering retail fuel prices to offset the impact of rising oil prices could strain the government's fiscal position. However, increasing fuel prices may lead to inflation concerns, potentially necessitating tighter monetary policy from the central bank, which could negatively affect market rates and borrowing costs.

India has benefited from relatively stable oil prices in recent years, allowing the government to collect higher tax revenues from fuel. But with the potential for increased oil price volatility due to geopolitical factors, the country may face new complexities and economic challenges.

headline: Trump says Zuckerberg told him he’s FB’s ‘No. 1’
article:
President Donald Trump boasted Monday that Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg told him at dinner he is “number one” on the global social media platform.

“I had dinner with Mark Zuckerberg the other day and he said ‘I’d like to congratulate you... you are number one on Facebook,’” Trump said.

The president, speaking in a live interview with right-wing radio talk show host Rush Limbaugh, did not specify when the dinner happened.

A spokesman for Facebook said the last such dinner took place in October.

The president noted the importance of social media to his messaging, which depends on bypassing much of the professional news media, which he accuses of bias against him.

Trump, who has nearly 70 million followers on Twitter, told Limbaugh that without the platform, “I think we’d be lost.”

“We wouldn’t be able to get the truth out,” he said.

US social media platforms have come under criticism for enabling misinformation and fake news in the build-up to the 2020 presidential election.

© 2019 All Rights Reserved. Powered by Summit
summary:
President Donald Trump claimed that Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg told him he is "number one" on the social media platform during a dinner. The exact timing of the dinner is unclear, but a Facebook spokesperson mentioned the last such dinner with Zuckerberg took place in October.

Trump emphasized the significance of social media in his communication strategy, particularly his reliance on platforms like Twitter to reach his audience. He expressed the belief that social media is essential for "getting the truth out" and circumventing what he perceives as bias in the professional news media.

The role of social media platforms, including Facebook and Twitter, in spreading information and misinformation has been a subject of scrutiny and debate, particularly in the lead-up to the 2020 presidential election.

headline: Productivity has big role in India’s $5 tn GDP dream
article:
The slowdown has revived interest in India’s growth rate as it aspires to become a $5 trillion economy. This would require growing at 8% in real terms, along with a 0.7% rise in total factor productivity (TFP). Mint explains the intricate relationship between TFP and growth.What are the factors for economic growth?

Economic growth is a function of the quantity of inputs such as labour and capital employed for productive purposes, along with factor productivity. It is intuitive that if more people are employed, more goods and services would be produced. Over time, due to a rise in population, labour employed increases and due to accumulation, capital also increases in an economy. A rise in productivity enables an economy to grow faster with the same set of labour and capital being employed. It is important to recognize the factors responsible for growth to address the current slowdown.What is total factor productivity?

Total factor productivity (TFP) is derived as a ratio of the total production and weighted average of inputs such as labour and capital. The measure gives us the growth in real output, which is in addition to the growth in inputs such as labour or capital employed for productive purposes. So TFP gives us the relationship between the quantity of factors employed and the output in an economy. A higher TFP implies higher growth with the same set of labour and capital employed. TFP as a concept was first discussed by Nikolaas Tinbergen (1942) and George Stigler (1947); Robert Solow (1957) developed the framework further.How has India’s TFP growth evolved over the years?

As per the Total Economy Database (TED), India’s adjusted GDP growth in 2005 was 9%, while TFP growth was 3.5%; in 2006, growth was 9.3% and TFP growth 3.3%; in 2007, the figures were 10.1% and 3.1%, respectively. Evidently, growth came with a substantial improvement in TFP. In 2016 India’s TFP growth was 3.5%, in 2017 it was 1.6% and in 2018 it was 2.4%.What is the global trend on TFP growth?

Since 2008, TFP growth has been slower for most nations; for China it has been negative since 2012. TED and Federal Reserve Economic Data on TFP and GDP growth show most economies with 8% or higher growth had TFP growth above 3%. These countries also saw a substantial rise in private capital formation in that period. Recent evidence indicates TFP might impact GDP growth more than fixed capital. Better TFP does seem to have a positive impact on growth of an economy, whether emerging or developed.What are the factors affecting TFP?

India can improve its TFP by undertaking bold market and structural reforms that will unshackle its productive capacity, stuck in the primary sector of the economy. Such reforms can cause reallocation of land and labour from primary to other sectors of the economy, thus enhancing productivity. Investments in physical infrastructure such as highways, dedicated freight corridors, and human capital will also increase TFP.

Karan Bhasin is a Delhi-based policy researcher.
summary:
ndia's aspiration to become a $5 trillion economy requires consistent economic growth. To achieve this, India would need to grow at an 8% real rate with a 0.7% increase in Total Factor Productivity (TFP). Understanding the relationship between TFP and economic growth is essential.

Factors for Economic Growth:
Economic growth relies on inputs such as labor and capital utilized for productive purposes, along with factor productivity. As more people are employed and capital accumulates over time, the quantity of labor and capital increases in an economy. Increased productivity enables an economy to grow more quickly using the same resources.

Total Factor Productivity (TFP):
TFP is calculated as the ratio of total production to the weighted average of inputs (e.g., labor and capital). It reflects the additional growth in real output beyond the growth in inputs. Higher TFP indicates greater growth with the same labor and capital inputs. TFP is a critical factor for achieving economic growth.

Evolution of TFP Growth in India:
India has seen fluctuations in TFP growth over the years. It played a significant role in India's economic growth between 2005 and 2007. However, in recent years, TFP growth has been inconsistent, which has contributed to the current economic slowdown.

Global Trend on TFP Growth:
Since 2008, TFP growth has been slower in most nations. China has experienced negative TFP growth since 2012. Nations with 8% or higher GDP growth typically had TFP growth above 3%. Recent evidence suggests that TFP might have a more substantial impact on GDP growth than fixed capital.

Factors Affecting TFP:
India can enhance its TFP by implementing market and structural reforms to unlock productive capacity, particularly in the primary sector of the economy. These reforms could facilitate the reallocation of land and labor from the primary sector to other sectors, leading to increased productivity. Investments in physical infrastructure, such as highways and human capital, can also boost TFP.

In summary, India's journey to a $5 trillion economy is closely linked to TFP growth. Implementing reforms and making strategic investments are vital steps in improving TFP and fostering sustainable economic growth.

headline: Death for rape
article:
The four convicts who were awarded death sentences for the horrific 2012 rape of a paramedical student aboard a bus in Delhi will be hanged in Tihar Jail on 22 January, according to a warrant issued by a city court. It was an attack of such brutality that it drew thousands of demonstrators onto the capital’s streets, demanding justice. Many believe that this demand is finally about to be met. As a case, it was indeed “rarest of rare”, the judiciary’s criterion for capital punishment.

Yet every execution should be an occasion for solemn reflection. Not just on such a penalty, but also on whether all rapists should routinely be put to death, as many Indians seem to want. The deterrent effect of a noose remains in dispute, even as few sexual crimes are open-and-shut cases. Conclusive evidence is hard to find, and judicial processes are imperfect. If the standards of evidence to pin guilt are kept loose, some innocents might end up at the gallows. If they’re kept strict, a lot of culprits might get away. And if the punishment is irreversible, our courts are likely to veer towards the latter. The country’s rape conviction rate is already low. It could drop further.
summary:
The four convicts who were sentenced to death for the brutal 2012 rape of a paramedical student aboard a bus in Delhi are set to be hanged on 22 January. The case sparked widespread protests and demands for justice. While this particular case met the judiciary's criteria for capital punishment as the "rarest of rare," it raises questions about whether all rapists should routinely receive the death penalty, as some Indians advocate.

The efficacy of the death penalty as a deterrent remains a subject of debate, and many sexual assault cases are complex with inconclusive evidence. Striking the right balance between strict standards of evidence to secure convictions and the risk of wrongful executions is challenging. India already has a low rape conviction rate, which could decrease further if capital punishment is widely imposed.

Each execution should be an occasion for solemn reflection, not only on the penalty itself but also on the broader questions surrounding the death penalty for sexual crimes.

headline: India Inc, put R&D where your mouth is
article:
PM Narendra Modi's strong pitch at the 108th Indian Science Congress for research & development (R&D) on Tuesday underlined the criticality of science and innovation for growth. The stress on taking science from the laboratory to everyday lives is a call for innovation that provides the basis for India's drive to be self-reliant. The focus on critical and emerging areas such as energy, sustainability, artificial intelligence (AI), quantum technologies, data sciences, development of new vaccines and surveillance for newer diseases will have maximum impact on growth, development and economic opportunities.

Modi's appeal took off from his 2022 Independence Day address where he had emphasised the need for ideas to be incubated, developed, tested and applied to real-life situations institutionally and not in an ad-hoc manner. An institutional framework alone can help create the structure for mentorship, access to opportunities and help convert research into real-world applications and opportunities. This, in turn, requires funding, institutional support and patience. India's R&D spending must increase from its low levels of 0.7% of GDP in 2017-18. This is less than half of the global average of 1.8%. Government spending accounts for 55-60% of R&D spending. Spending by private entities, businesses and educational institutions must go up.

India's R&D should focus on leveraging low-cost, accessible technology to meet the developmental needs of its population. It is time to put one's money where one's mouth is when it comes to talking about unlocking our demographic dividend.
summary: PM Modi emphasised the importance of R&D for India's growth at the Indian Science Congress. He called for taking science from the lab to people's lives through innovation. Focusing R&D on critical areas like energy, AI and healthcare can boost development. Modi wants an institutional framework to patent, test and apply ideas solution, which needs increased funding from both public and private sectors. India's R&D should leverage affordable tech to meet population's needs.

headline: Three deaths reported in Bangalore following heavy rain
article: Following heavy overnight rain on Wednesday, three persons were killed in two separate incidents in Bangalore. In one incident, a 37-year-old man was killed along with his 10-year-old son when a two storey building collapsed on them at around 1.30 am on Thursday at Jogupalya in the limits of the Ulsoor police station in east Bangalore. The deceased were identified as Subramani, an employee at a private firm and his son Kiran Sai, a class III student in a government school in the locality. Subramani had stepped outside his house along with his son to park his motorcycle at a safe location when the incident occurred. He was about to move his bike from the street when the building collapsed, assistant commissioner of police (Ulsoor Sub-division) GB Manjunath said. The victim’s bodies were recovered from the debris of building by a Fire and Emergency Services rescue team. Police said that Subramani’s wife Bharati and another son who were inside the house were safe. City in-charge minister Ramalinga Reddy and local legislator NA Haris visited the scene of the building collapse. Reddy announced a Rs two lakh compensation to the kin of the deceased. In another incident, a 40-year-old priest at the Sri Sai Temple in Basaveshwara Nagar in West Bangalore was electrocuted on Thursday morning when he was trying to pump out water that had collected in the cellar of the temple due to heavy overnight rain. The priest Shankar stepped on a live electric wire in the cellar while pumping out water and was killed at the spot.
summary: In Bangalore, heavy rain led to two tragic incidents. In the first, a 37-year-old man and his 10-year-old son lost their lives when a two-story building collapsed on them while they were parking a motorcycle. Fortunately, the rest of the family was safe. In the second incident, a 40-year-old priest was electrocuted while trying to pump out water from a temple's cellar. The rain caused dangerous conditions, resulting in these unfortunate accidents.

headline: Jharkhand govt plans to seek denotification of Parasnath hill from eco-sensitive zone
article:
Amid protests by the Jain community across the country over the declaration of Parasnath hills as a tourist spot, the Jharkhand government is considering denotification of the area from the eco-sensitive zone (ESZ) tag.

Last week, the Union Environment ministry had taken cognisance of the representations it had received on the issue and had written to the state government to consider denotification of the ESZ area. It has been assessed that keeping just two of the affected village areas out
of the ESZ notification will address the concerns of the protesters.
The central government had notified the area as eco-sensitive zone in
August 2019 based on the state government's proposal. The notification
also gave a mandate to the state government to prepare a tourism
development plan for the area.
Sources told ET that the Jharkhand government led by chief minister
Hemant Soren is likely to hold a meeting to take a decision and the
state government will write to the Centre for the denotification.
"The state government is committed to preserve the sanctity of the
place in consonance with the feelings of the Jain community. The
government has already directed the local administration to not serve
liquor and non-vegetarian food in the area. Besides, the state
government in its Tourism Policy 2022 specifically mandates the
tourism department to develop Parasnath hills as a Jain Pilgrimage
centre," Vinay Choubey, secretary to Jharkhand chief minister, told
ET.
"The central government has notified Parasnath hills as an
eco-sensitive zone and has given the mandate to the state government
to prepare a tourism development plan. But no action has been taken on
ground by the state government and in future also no action will be
taken which would be against the sensitivity of the Jain pilgrims." In
February 2019, the earlier Jharkhand government announced a list of
places as places of importance for international tourism.
summary: Amid protests by Jains over Parasnath hills' ESZ tag, the Jharkhand government is considering removing the designation to address concerns. The area was notified as ESZ in 2019 based on the state's proposal, but no tourism plan was made. CM Hemant Soren is likely to meet over the issue and ask the Centre to cancel the ESZ notification as developing tourism there could hurt Jain pilgrims' sensitivities.

headline: Army & IAF launch air ops, rescue 354 tourists
article: Five days after flash floods struck Sikkim, the Army and Air Force launched airborne rescue operations on Monday to evacuate people stranded in Lachen and Lachung in North Sikkim. The MI-17 and Chinook helicopters under the Indian Air Force conducted 10 rounds successfully from Lachung, evacuating 354 tourists, including 13 tourists from Bangladesh. It also carried emergency service personnel and essential supplies to Lachen. According to defence spokesperson Wing Commander Himanshu Tiwari, the IAF carried 217 tourists in Chinook and Mi-17V5 helicopters, operating from Bagdogra Air Force Station, in multiple sorties from various Army bases to safer locations. The evacuation procedure will again resume in the first hour on Tuesday.
summary: The Indian Army and Air Force launched an airborne rescue operation in response to flash floods in Sikkim. MI-17 and Chinook helicopters successfully conducted 10 rounds of evacuations in Lachen and Lachung, rescuing 354 tourists, including 13 from Bangladesh. They also transported emergency personnel and supplies to Lachen. The Indian Air Force airlifted 217 tourists from various Army bases to safer locations using Chinook and Mi-17V5 helicopters. The operation will continue on Tuesday.

headline: The link between growth, demand and investment
article:
As per the government’s first advance estimate, gross domestic product (GDP) growth for FY20 is likely to be 5%—the lowest since the global financial crisis of 2008-09, when it fell to 3.1%. To examine the fall, Mint takes a detailed look at India’s GDP numbers.

Private consumption expenditure, the money you and I spend on buying things, has comprised 56-57% of India’s GDP (in real terms, adjusted for inflation) over the past few years. In FY20, it is expected to grow at 5.8%, after growing at over 7.4% in each of the last four fiscals. This can clearly be seen in the fall in sales of cars, two-wheelers and tractors, and the slower volume growth of FMCG companies. People are not spending as much money on buying things as they used to, given the lack of confidence they have in their economic future. This is reflected in slow growth of private consumption expenditure.
What is investment’s part in the fall?

Investment is a key driver of consumption. Investment growth in FY20 is expected to collapse to 1%, the lowest since FY06 (i.e., as far back as growth data for the current GDP series goes). Without proper investment growth, jobs can’t be created. And without jobs, there won’t be a source of income for the million Indians entering the workforce every month. Only when people earn can they spend. Also, one man’s expenditure is another man’s income—creating a cycle. Hence, a slowdown in investment growth is bound to affect private consumption, which, in turn, will slow down GDP growth in FY20.What is the state of government expenditure?

Government expenditure—growing 9.3% in FY19 and 15% in FY18—has driven growth between 2017-19. In FY20, it is expected to grow 10.5%, the fastest among all constituents of GDP (others being private consumption expenditure, investment and net exports). This fiscal, the government’s share in the economy will reach 11.3%, the highest in a decade.What about the non-govt part of economy?

If we leave government expenditure out of the GDP, what remains is the non-government part of the economy. This part is expected to grow at 4.3% in FY20—the lowest since 2008-09, when it had grown 2.2%. This is hardly surprising given the slow private consumption growth and plunging investment growth. The non-government component forms around 90% of the economy, and it’s this part that needs a boost if the overall economy is to be revived. Higher government spending can only do so much.So what can the government do?

In the short run, consumption growth needs to be revived, without which investments are unlikely to improve. Companies invest when people consume. To ensure this, the government can put more money in the hands of people via a personal income tax cut, and spend more on social schemes, such as MGNREGS. Also, the GST Council needs to stop fiddling around with the goods and services tax and go for a comprehensive overhaul. Vivek Kaul is an economist and the author of the Easy Money trilogy.
summary: India's GDP growth for FY20 is estimated to be 5%, the lowest since the global financial crisis in 2008-09. The fall can be attributed to declining private consumption expenditure and a collapse in investment growth. Investment is crucial as it drives consumption, job creation, and income generation. The government's expenditure has played a significant role in driving growth, while the non-government part of the economy, comprising 90% of GDP, is expected to grow at its lowest rate since 2008-09. To revive the economy, policies aimed at boosting consumption and investment are essential, such as tax cuts and increased spending on social schemes.

headline: Adele suffers from sciatica. What is it, here's all you need to know about the condition
article:
Adele suffers from sciatica. See what it is Agencies
At one of her recent shows on New Year’s Eve, English
singer-songwriter Adele disclosed that she is battling sciatica. 
Adele talked to the audience and revealed that she is suffering from
the condition while walking from one end of the stage to another when
she was hosting a show on New Year’s Eve (December 31, 2022) at The
Colosseum. 
During the concert, the 34-year-old singer, while firing T-shirts
towards the crowd with the help of a handheld cannon, said that she
has just got to get over to the other side of the stage and she has to
wobble for it these days due to sciatica. It seems to have been
causing pain in her lower back. 
WHAT IS SCIATICA?
Sciatica happens when pain travels along the sciatic nerve, which runs
from the lower back via the buttocks and hips to each leg.
The pain in the sciatic nerve can be severe, but it can be fixed in a
matter of weeks. It generally occurs when an overgrowth of bone or a
herniated disk in the spine puts pressure on the nerve. It leads to
pain, inflammation and numbness in the affected leg.
In some rare cases, a tumor can also put pressure on the nerve.
Conditions like diabetes can also damage the nerve leading to the
issue.
Adele has talked about her health problems earlier as well. In
November 2021, while speaking to a magazine, she spoke about how her
life has changed after weight loss.
English singer-songwriter added that she is certainly happy now
because she is "more agile" and can move about more now that she has
lost weight. Adele then discussed her long-standing back problems.
summary: Singer Adele recently revealed she is suffering from sciatica, a pain that travels along the sciatic nerve from lower back down the legs. During a New Year's Eve concert, she said she has to wobble when walking on stage due to the back pain caused by the condition. Sciatica occurs due to pressure on the nerve from issues like slipped disk or bone overgrowth in the spine.

headline: India’s coal call
article:
The Union cabinet on Wednesday approved an ordinance that should attract investment and help modernize India’s under-exploited and inefficient coal sector. The Mineral Laws (Amendment) Ordinance, 2020, will end the restrictive end-use criterion for coal-mine block allocations. The extant rules bar companies other than coal washeries and those that need it as raw material, such as power generators and iron and steel makers, from bidding for coal mines. The ordinance opens up mining to all firms with offices registered in India.

The move promises to expedite projects and paves the way for commercial mining. It aims to reduce coal imports, and may soon end Coal India Ltd’s monopoly on sales. The Centre is keen to auction some coal blocks before the end of FY20, as its finances look stretched and it urgently needs money to close the gap between its revenues and expenses. As a result of the end-use restriction, India had been able to hawk no more than 29 coal blocks since the Supreme Court cancelled the allotment of more than 200 blocks in 2014. With that clamp gone, global miners such as BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto are expected to enter the field.

© 2019 All Rights Reserved. Powered by Summit
summary: The Indian government has approved an ordinance to attract investment and modernize the coal sector. The Mineral Laws (Amendment) Ordinance, 2020, eliminates restrictive end-use criteria for coal-mine block allocations. Previously, only specific entities like coal washeries and power generators were allowed to bid for coal mines. The new ordinance opens up mining to all firms with registered offices in India, paving the way for commercial mining and potentially reducing coal imports. The government is keen to auction coal blocks to boost revenues and end the monopoly of Coal India Ltd. Global miners like BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto are expected to enter the market.

headline: Air pollution may lead to schizophrenia: study
article:
Children who grow up in areas with heavy air pollution have a higher risk of developing schizophrenia, according to a study which suggests that particulate matter in air may not only harm physical well-being, but also mental health.

The study, published in the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA), assessed genetic data from iPSYCH—a project to find the basis and treatment of the most common and serious mental illnesses, including autism, bipolar disorder, and depression. The researchers, including those from Aarhus University in Denmark, combined the iPSYCH data with information on air pollution from the country’s department of environmental science.

For each 10 microgramme per cubic metre increase in the daily average of air pollution, the risk of schizophrenia increased by a fifth, the researchers reported in the study.

To put the findings in perspective, the researchers said the lifetime risk of developing schizophrenia is approximately 2% for people, but for those exposed to the highest level of air pollution, this risk is 3%.

© 2019 All Rights Reserved. Powered by Summit
summary: A recent study suggests that children growing up in areas with heavy air pollution may have an increased risk of developing schizophrenia. The study, which combined genetic data with information on air pollution, found that for each 10 microgram per cubic meter increase in daily average air pollution, the risk of schizophrenia increased by 20%. While the lifetime risk of developing schizophrenia is approximately 2% for people, it rises to 3% for those exposed to the highest levels of air pollution. The study highlights the potential impact of air pollution on mental health in addition to its known physical health effects.

headline: IMF sees India as a bright spot, says reforms will spur growth
article:
Comment
Synopsis
SAYEH SAID INDIA NEEDS TO LEVERAGE ITS EXISTING STRENGTH IN SERVICES
EXPORTS AND EXTEND IT TO JOB-RICH MANUFACTURING EXPORTS BY DEEPENING
ITS GLOBAL VALUE CHAIN PARTICIPATION AND COMPLEMENTARY STRUCTURAL
REFORMS THAT CAN BOOST PRODUCTIVITY, FORMAL EMPLOYMENT AND EXPORTS.
 India in a relative 'bright spot', must leverage exports, says IMF
official AgenciesImage used for representational purpose only
India is a relative "bright spot" in the world economy and further
implementation of reforms would help unlock its growth potential, a
top International Monetary Fund official said Friday. "India is a
relative bright spot in the world economy today, growing at rates
significantly above its peer average," IMF deputy managing director
Antoinette Sayeh said at a book release function.
Sayeh said India needs to leverage its existing strength in services
exports and extend it to job-rich manufacturing exports by deepening
its global value chain participation and complementary structural
reforms that can boost productivity, formal employment and exports.
"Doing so would create a virtuous cycle of productivity growth and
strong export performance," she said.
 Screenshot 2023-01-06 235953 ET Bureau
IMF has forecast a 6.8% growth for India in FY23, which is projected
to slow to 6.1% in FY24.
Sayeh said macroeconomic policies were responding to the significant
headwinds, with fiscal policy measures supporting vulnerable groups
