Two youngsters from the Telugu speaking states — Shaik Rasheed from Guntur (Andhra Pradesh) and Nirvetla Rishith Reddy from Hyderabad (Telangana) — were part of the winning team. They share the excitement about wearing the ‘blue jersey’ and their journey so far — and the historic win.
summary: Team India secured a fantastic victory by defeating England by four wickets in the ICC U-19 World Cup final in Antigua. This triumph marked India's fifth U19 World Cup title, extending their record. Notably, two young talents from Telugu-speaking states, Shaik Rasheed from Guntur in Andhra Pradesh and Nirvetla Rishith Reddy from Hyderabad in Telangana, played pivotal roles in this winning team. These young cricketers are elated to be part of the team and wear the cherished 'blue jersey.' They shared their excitement about their remarkable journey and the historic win in the U-19 World Cup.

headline: India condemns attack on 17-year-old Sikh high school student in Canada
article: TORONTO: India on Saturday strongly condemned an assault, including the use of bear spray, on a 17-year-old Sikh high school student in Canada's British Columbia province this week and urged local authorities to investigate the incident and take prompt action against the perpetrators. The incident took place on September 11 when the Sikh student, who has not been named, was on his way home from school in Kelowna. Kelowna Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) said in a statement on September 11 that the attack occurred just before 4 p.m. at a bus stop at the intersection of Rutland Road and Robson Road in the Okanagan city.
summary: India has strongly condemned a distressing incident in Canada's British Columbia province where a 17-year-old Sikh high school student was assaulted, including the use of bear spray. This incident took place on September 11 as the student was heading home from school in Kelowna. The Kelowna Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) reported that the attack occurred just before 4 p.m. at a bus stop located at the intersection of Rutland Road and Robson Road in the city of Okanagan. India has urged local authorities to thoroughly investigate the incident and take swift action against those responsible for this attack.

headline: Workplace recognition, not salary tops job seekers' mind in India
article:
When it comes to job search, employees are no longer fixated on the take-home amount and look beyond monetary payouts, according to a report on Wednesday.
The report by job platform Naukri.com showed that impact of work, work culture, and job location are the top three factors that employees value the most with their job preferences. Impact of work was voted high by around 66 per cent of respondents followed by work culture (64 per cent), and job location (62 per cent). While female employees preferred quality and impact of work (66 per cent) the most, followed by job location (62 per cent), males voted for work culture (65 per cent) as more important than the job location.
summary: In the realm of job searching, employees have shifted their focus from simply the paycheck and are now considering factors beyond financial rewards. This insight comes from a report released on a Wednesday. According to the report from Naukri.com, the most significant factors that employees now prioritize in their job preferences are the impact of their work, the work culture, and the job location. Approximately 66 percent of the respondents emphasized the importance of the impact of their work, followed closely by work culture at 64 percent and job location at 62 percent. Interestingly, there were some differences between male and female employees. Female employees valued the quality and impact of their work the most (66 percent), followed by job location at 62 percent. In contrast, male employees placed more importance on work culture (65 percent) than job location in their job preferences.

article: Anil Kapoor has 'disappeared' from his Instagram, and his producer-brother, Boney Kapoor explained if this is a major hint for the much-awaited Mr India 2. headline: Alarm bells start ringning as monsoon plays truant
article:
The Indian Express article "Alarm bells start ringing as monsoon plays truant" on July 13, 2004, reports on the growing concern about the delayed monsoon in India. The monsoon is essential for India's agriculture sector, and any delay in its arrival can have a devastating impact on the country's economy and food security.

The article states that the monsoon was already two weeks late in some parts of India, and that there was no sign of it arriving anytime soon. This was causing widespread anxiety among farmers, who were worried that their crops would fail if the monsoon did not arrive soon.

The article also quotes experts who say that the delayed monsoon is likely due to a combination of factors, including climate change and El Nino. The experts warn that the delayed monsoon could lead to widespread drought in India, and that this could have a severe impact on the country's economy and food security.

The article concludes by stating that the Indian government is taking steps to mitigate the impact of the delayed monsoon, including providing financial assistance to farmers and releasing water from reservoirs. However, the experts warn that these measures will not be enough to prevent a drought if the monsoon does not arrive soon.
summary:
The monsoon is essential for India's agriculture sector, and any delay in its arrival can have a devastating impact on the country's economy and food security.
The monsoon was already two weeks late in some parts of India in July 2004, and there was no sign of it arriving anytime soon.
This was causing widespread anxiety among farmers, who were worried that their crops would fail if the monsoon did not arrive soon.
Experts say that the delayed monsoon is likely due to a combination of factors, including climate change and El Nino.
The experts warn that the delayed monsoon could lead to widespread drought in India, and that this could have a severe impact on the country's economy and food security.
The Indian government is taking steps to mitigate the impact of the delayed monsoon, but the experts warn that these measures will not be enough to prevent a drought if the monsoon does not arrive soon.

headline: Rajnath: PLA's Violent conduct completely violates all Norms
article:
Defence Minister Rajnath Singh on Wednesday said that the Chinese People's Liberation Army's (PLA) violent conduct completely violates all norms and agreements between India and China.

"The PLA's violent conduct completely violates all norms and agreements between India and China. India has taken strong measures to safeguard its borders. We are committed to resolving the issue peacefully," Singh said in a statement.

Singh's statement comes after a violent clash between Indian and Chinese troops in Galwan Valley, Ladakh, on June 15, 2020, in which 20 Indian soldiers were killed. The PLA also suffered casualties, but the exact number is unknown.

The clash was the deadliest between Indian and Chinese troops since 1975. It has led to a significant increase in tensions between the two countries.

Singh said that India has taken strong measures to safeguard its borders. He said that the Indian Army is fully prepared to deal with any challenge from the PLA.

"Our armed forces are fully prepared to deal with any challenge. We are committed to resolving the issue peacefully. However, we will not compromise on our national security," Singh said.

The Indian government has said that it is committed to resolving the issue with China through dialogue and diplomacy. However, it has also said that it will not be intimidated by the PLA's aggressive behavior.

The clash in Galwan Valley has raised concerns about the possibility of a war between India and China. However, both countries have said that they do not want war.
summary:
Defence Minister Rajnath Singh said that the Chinese People's Liberation Army's (PLA) violent conduct in Galwan Valley, Ladakh, on June 15, 2020, completely violates all norms and agreements between India and China.

Singh said that India has taken strong measures to safeguard its borders and that the Indian Army is fully prepared to deal with any challenge from the PLA. He said that India is committed to resolving the issue peacefully, but will not compromise on its national security.

headline: India World Champions
article:
India scripted history at Lord's on Sunday as they lifted the Prudential World Cup for the first time, defeating the West Indies by 43 runs in the final.

India won the toss and elected to bat first. They were off to a steady start as Kris Srikkanth and Sunil Gavaskar put on 75 runs for the first wicket. However, the West Indies bowlers then struck back, taking three quick wickets to leave India reeling at 87 for 3.

But Kapil Dev and Mohinder Amarnath then put on a crucial partnership of 126 runs for the fourth wicket. Dev was dismissed for 66, but Amarnath went on to score a brilliant century (103). He was eventually dismissed for 103, but by then India had reached a respectable total of 183 runs.

The West Indies were the favorites to win the final, but they were undone by some excellent bowling from the Indian bowlers. Madan Lal and Roger Binny took three wickets each, while Kapil Dev and Ravi Shastri took two wickets each. The West Indies were bowled out for 140 runs in 52 overs, and India won the match by 43 runs.

India's victory in the World Cup was a historic moment for the country. It was the first time that India had won a major world title in cricket. The victory was also a testament to the skill and determination of the Indian team.
summary:
India defeated the West Indies by 43 runs in the final of the 1983 Prudential World Cup to win the tournament for the first time. It was a historic moment for the country, and it was a testament to the skill and determination of the Indian team.

India's victory in the World Cup was a historic moment for the country. It was the first time that India had won a major world title in cricket, and it was a testament to the skill and determination of the Indian team. The victory also had a significant impact on the country as a whole, inspiring a generation of cricketers and helping to make cricket the most popular sport in India.

headline: INDIAN STRIKES
article:
India launched surgical strikes against suspected militants in Pakistani-administered Kashmir on Thursday night, in a major escalation of tensions between the two nuclear-armed rivals.

The Indian Army said that it had carried out the strikes "on terrorist launch pads" across the Line of Control (LoC), the de facto border between India and Pakistan in Kashmir. The army said that the strikes had been successful and that it had inflicted "significant casualties" on the militants.

The Pakistani military denied that India had carried out any surgical strikes, and said that Indian troops had only fired across the LoC, killing two Pakistani soldiers.

The Indian Army's strikes come in the wake of the deadly attack on an Indian army camp at Uri in Jammu and Kashmir on September 18, in which 19 Indian soldiers were killed. India has blamed Pakistan for the Uri attack, and has demanded that Pakistan take action against the perpetrators.

Pakistan has denied any involvement in the Uri attack, and has accused India of trying to escalate tensions between the two countries.

The Indian Army's strikes are a significant development, as it is the first time that India has carried out a cross-border counter-terrorism operation since the Kargil War in 1999. The strikes are also a sign of India's growing frustration with Pakistan's continued support for terrorism in Kashmir.

The strikes are likely to further escalate tensions between India and Pakistan, and there is a risk that the situation could spiral out of control. It is important for both countries to exercise restraint and to avoid taking any further provocative actions.
summary:
India launched surgical strikes against suspected militants in Pakistani-administered Kashmir in response to the deadly attack on an Indian army camp at Uri in Jammu and Kashmir. The strikes are a significant escalation of tensions between the two nuclear-armed rivals, and there is a risk that the situation could spiral out of control. It is important for both countries to exercise restraint and to avoid taking any further provocative actions.

India carried out surgical strikes against suspected militants in Pakistani-administered Kashmir in response to a terrorist attack on an Indian army camp. The strikes are a significant escalation of tensions between India and Pakistan.

headline: Harsimrat quits as minister in protest against agri bills
article:
Harsimrat Kaur Badal, the Union Minister of Food Processing Industries, resigned from her post on Thursday in protest against the three farm bills that were passed by the Parliament earlier this week.

Badal, who is the wife of Akali Dal patriarch Parkash Singh Badal, said that she could not continue in the government when it was bringing in laws that would harm the farmers of Punjab.

In a letter to Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Badal said, "I have resigned from the Union Cabinet in protest against the anti-farmer ordinances and the manner in which they were passed through Parliament."

Badal's resignation is a major blow to the Modi government, as the Akali Dal is a key ally of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in Punjab. The Akali Dal has been opposing the farm bills, saying that they will harm the interests of farmers.

The farm bills have been controversial since they were introduced by the government in June. The bills have been criticized by farmers' groups, opposition parties, and economists. However, the government has defended the bills, saying that they are necessary to reform the agricultural sector.

Badal's resignation is likely to put further pressure on the Modi government to reconsider the farm bills. The government is already facing protests from farmers in Punjab, Haryana, and other states.
summary: Harsimrat Kaur Badal, the Union Minister of Food Processing Industries, resigned from her post on Thursday in protest against the three farm bills that were passed by the Parliament earlier this week. Badal, who is the wife of Akali Dal patriarch Parkash Singh Badal, said that she could not continue in the government when it was bringing in laws that would harm the farmers of Punjab. Badal's resignation is a major blow to the Modi government, as the Akali Dal is a key ally of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in Punjab.

headline: SEBI plans new rules to check insider trading
article:
The Mint article "SEBI plans new rules to check insider trading" on August 22, 2004, reports on the Securities and Exchange Board of India's (SEBI) plans to introduce new rules to check insider trading. Insider trading is the illegal practice of buying or selling securities based on material, non-public information. SEBI is India's market regulator, and it is responsible for protecting the interests of investors in the Indian securities market.

The article states that SEBI is proposing a number of new rules to check insider trading, including:

A requirement for companies to disclose all material information to the public on a timely basis.
A ban on insider trading by company directors and other insiders.
A requirement for companies to have a code of conduct in place to prevent insider trading.
Increased penalties for insider trading.
The article also quotes experts who say that the new rules are welcome, but that they need to be implemented effectively. The experts also say that SEBI needs to increase its surveillance of the market and take action against those who violate the insider trading rules.

The article concludes by stating that the new rules are expected to help to reduce insider trading in the Indian securities market, and to protect the interests of investors.
summary:
SEBI is proposing a number of new rules to check insider trading, including a requirement for companies to disclose all material information to the public on a timely basis, a ban on insider trading by company directors and other insiders, a requirement for companies to have a code of conduct in place to prevent insider trading, and increased penalties for insider trading.
Experts say that the new rules are welcome, but that they need to be implemented effectively and that SEBI needs to increase its surveillance of the market and take action against those who violate the insider trading rules.
The new rules are expected to help to reduce insider trading in the Indian securities market, and to protect the interests of investors.

headline: India and Pakistan sign trade agreement
article:
The agreement was signed by the Indian Commerce and Industry Minister Kamal Nath and the Pakistani Commerce Minister Humayun Akhtar Khan. The agreement was aimed at increasing trade between the two countries and improving economic relations.

The agreement included a number of provisions, including:

A reduction in tariffs on a number of items, including textiles, agricultural products, and engineering goods.
An expansion of the list of items that could be traded between the two countries.
Measures to simplify customs procedures and reduce trade barriers.
The establishment of a Joint Trade Commission to oversee the implementation of the agreement.
The trade agreement was welcomed by both the Indian and Pakistani governments, and by the business community in both countries. It was seen as a positive step towards improving relations between the two countries and boosting economic growth in both economies.

However, the trade agreement has not been fully implemented. Trade between India and Pakistan remains low, and there are a number of non-tariff barriers that continue to hinder trade. Nevertheless, the trade agreement is still seen as a significant step forward, and it is hoped that it will eventually lead to increased trade and improved economic relations between the two countries.
summary:
India and Pakistan signed a trade agreement on June 29, 2005, with the goal of increasing trade between the two countries and improving economic relations. The agreement included a reduction in tariffs on a number of items, an expansion of the list of items that could be traded, measures to simplify customs procedures, and the establishment of a Joint Trade Commission to oversee the implementation of the agreement.

The trade agreement was welcomed by both the Indian and Pakistani governments, and by the business community in both countries. It was seen as a positive step towards improving relations between the two countries and boosting economic growth in both economies.

However, the trade agreement has not been fully implemented. Trade between India and Pakistan remains low, and there are a number of non-tariff barriers that continue to hinder trade. Nevertheless, the trade agreement is still seen as a significant step forward, and it is hoped that it will eventually lead to increased trade and improved economic relations between the two countries.

headline: "Pakistani Forces Attack Chhamb"
article:
The headline "Pakistani Forces Attack Chhamb" in The Hindu on September 1, 1965, marked the beginning of the Second Indo-Pakistani War. The war was fought between India and Pakistan over the disputed territory of Kashmir.

**Background**

The Kashmir conflict is a territorial dispute between India and Pakistan over the Kashmir region, which has been the cause of two wars between the two countries. The region is primarily Muslim-majority, but it is also home to a significant Hindu minority.

The conflict began in 1947, when India and Pakistan gained independence from British rule. The princely state of Kashmir was given the option to join either India or Pakistan. The ruler of Kashmir, Maharaja Hari Singh, was Hindu, but the majority of the population was Muslim. He initially declared Kashmir independent, but later decided to join India. This decision led to an armed rebellion by the Muslim population of Kashmir, who were supported by Pakistan.

The first Indo-Pakistani War broke out in 1947 and ended with a ceasefire in 1949. The ceasefire line that divides Kashmir into Indian-administered Kashmir and Pakistani-administered Kashmir is known as the Line of Control (LoC).

**The 1965 War**

The Second Indo-Pakistani War began on September 1, 1965, when Pakistani forces attacked Chhamb, a strategically important town in Jammu and Kashmir, located near the border with Pakistan. The Pakistani attack was seen as an attempt to cut off the road between Jammu and Srinagar, the capital of Jammu and Kashmir.

The Indian army responded quickly to the Pakistani attack. Indian forces were able to repel the Pakistani attack and secure Chhamb. However, the war continued for several weeks, with both sides suffering heavy casualties.

The war ended with the signing of the Tashkent Agreement on January 10, 1966. The Tashkent Agreement was a ceasefire agreement that restored the status quo ante bellum, meaning that both sides agreed to withdraw to their pre-war positions.

**Impact of the War**

The Second Indo-Pakistani War was a major turning point in the history of the two countries. It led to a significant increase in military spending and a deterioration in relations between India and Pakistan. The war also had a significant impact on the people of Kashmir, who continued to suffer from the conflict for many years to come.

**Conclusion**

The Second Indo-Pakistani War was a major conflict with a significant impact on the two countries and the people of Kashmir. The war led to a deterioration in relations between India and Pakistan, and it continues to have an impact on the region to this day.
summary: The Second Indo-Pakistani War was a major conflict fought between India and Pakistan over the disputed territory of Kashmir. The war began on September 1, 1965, when Pakistani forces attacked Chhamb, a strategically important town in Jammu and Kashmir. The Indian army responded quickly and was able to repel the Pakistani attack and secure Chhamb. However, the war continued for several weeks, with both sides suffering heavy casualties. The war ended with the signing of the Tashkent Agreement on January 10, 1966. The Tashkent Agreement was a ceasefire agreement that restored the status quo ante bellum, meaning that both sides agreed to withdraw to their pre-war positions. The Second Indo-Pakistani War was a major turning point in the history of the two countries. It led to a significant increase in military spending and a deterioration in relations between India and Pakistan. The war also had a significant impact on the people of Kashmir, who continued to suffer from the conflict for many years to come.

headline: Runners-up: Pakistan
article: After hosting World Cup in 1975, 1979 and 1983, the International Cricket Council brought the World Cup back to England after a gap of 16 years. Apart from the nine Test playing nations, minnows Scotland, Kenya and Bangladesh participated in the competition. The tournament was categorized into two groups of six. South Africans started as the favorites after their splendid form in 12 months prior to the World Cup.
summary:
The first World Cup final held at Lord’s in 1975 lasted almost a full day, nearly 10 hours. This one was over shortly after it started. The final between Pakistan and Australia had the no-smell of contest to it, but to suggest it was fixed was absolutely absurd. 
At the beginning of the World Cup, Aussies looked strangely out of sorts losing to New Zealand and Pakistan. Thereafter, they went on to win seven successive matches.
When Australia had gone to Old Trafford earlier for their final group match, they were in severe danger of the earliest possible exit. In the last Super Six match, Australian journalists and officials had been making calls to check on airline seat availability, which would have been firmed up had Herschelle Gibbs not celebrated too soon and thrown away a catch offered by Steve Waugh. Waugh went on to make 120 off 110 balls with 10 fours and two sixes and chased 271.
In the semi-final four days later, as Damien Fleming prepared to bowl to Lance Klusener – the player of the tournament – with South Africa needing just one to win, there came the biggest laughable error in the World Cup history. Klusener and Allan Donald had a horrendous running mix-up, the match was tied, and Australia went through on net run-rate..
Australia’s improbable lurch into the final after winning those cliffhangers was in total contrast to their opponents’ confident march. The Pakistanis lost three successive games which did not matter, but returned to form in time to earn their place at Lord’s by blowing Zimbabwe and New Zealand away by huge margins.

headline: Low pressure forms over Bay of Bengal; Odisha to witness rain during Dusshera
article:
A low-pressure area has formed over Bay of Bengal...,” the India Meteorological Department's (IMD) regional centre in Bhubaneswar said on X.
With the formation of a low-pressure area in the Bay of Bengal on Friday, Odisha's coastal districts are likely to witness a wet Dusshera as the IMD has predicted rains from October 23.
summary:
A low-pressure system has developed over the Bay of Bengal, and as a result, Odisha is expected to experience rainfall during the Dussehra festival. This meteorological event is significant for the region as it can impact festivities and agricultural activities.

Low-pressure systems in the Bay of Bengal are common during the monsoon season and can bring heavy rainfall. The timing of this particular system coincides with the Dussehra festival, a major Hindu celebration, and the rainfall may disrupt outdoor ceremonies and processions. Farmers may be concerned about the potential impact on their crops, as excess rainfall can lead to waterlogging and crop damage.

It's essential for residents of Odisha to stay updated on weather forecasts and be prepared for the possibility of rain during the festive period. Additionally, local authorities should take precautionary measures to ensure the safety of the public, especially in areas prone to flooding.

headline: Canada PM Trudeau says India making life hard for millions of people amid diplomatic crisis
article:
Trudeau's comment comes as Canada withdraws 41 diplomats from India and calls India's move ‘unreasonable and escalatory’.
Canada Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Friday said India's actions are making life very hard for millions of people in India and Canada after Canada confirmed the withdrawal of 41 diplomats from India adding that this will delay the visa services in India. Canada called India's move unreasonable and escalatory as New Delhi asked Ottawa to reduce its diplomatic presence in India -- so that there is a parity as India has a far lesser number of diplomats present in Canada. headline: Republicans drop Jim Jordan as their nominee for House speaker
article:

Republicans dropped Rep. Jim Jordan on Friday as their nominee for House speaker, making the decision during a closed-door session after the hard-edged ally of Donald Trump failed badly on a third ballot for the gavel.

headline: MMRDA gets nod for twin tunnels under SGNP; 122 trees to be felled for CM Shinde’s pet project
article:
The State Board of Wildlife has approved a proposal to cut 122 trees in Sanjay Gandhi National Park to build tunnels connecting Borivali to Thane in Mumbai. The project has faced criticism from environmentalists due to potential harm to wildlife and ecological damage.
: The State Board of Wildlife has approved a proposal allowing Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority (MMRDA) to cut 122 trees in the core area and the eco-sensitive zone (ESZ) of Sanjay Gandhi National Park (SGNP) to build twin tunnels connecting Borivali to Thane, people familiar with the development said. headline: Indian Army Crosses International Border
article:

The article stated that the Indian Army had crossed the border in several places in the Punjab sector, including at Wagah, Khalra, and Khemkaran. The attack caught the Pakistani Army by surprise, and the Indian forces were able to make significant gains in the early hours of the operation.

The crossing of the international border by the Indian Army was a significant escalation of the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965. The war had begun in August with Pakistani infiltrators crossing into Kashmir. India responded by launching a counter-offensive, and the war quickly spread to the international border.

The war ended in September 1965 with the signing of the Tashkent Agreement. The agreement restored the status quo ante bellum, but it did not resolve the underlying issue of Kashmir.

The war led to a significant increase in military spending and to a hardening of attitudes on both sides. headline: The Black Buck Stops Here, Says Modi
article:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Wednesday took full responsibility for the demonetization of Rs 500 and Rs 1000 notes, saying that the black buck stops here.

In a televised address to the nation, Modi said that the decision to demonetize the high-value notes was taken to curb black money and corruption. He said that the decision was not easy, but it was necessary to cleanse the economy.

headline: "Lahore Captured by Indian Forces"
article:

The article stated that the Indian Army had launched a coordinated attack on Lahore from three sides on September 6. The Indian forces had faced stiff resistance from the Pakistani Army, but they had managed to break through the Pakistani defenses and capture the city on September 7.

headline: "UN Security Council Calls for Ceasefire"
article:
The article "UN Security Council Calls for Ceasefire" in The Hindu on September 20, 1965, reported on the United Nations Security Council's call for a ceasefire between India and Pakistan in the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965.

The Security Council had passed a resolution on September 19 calling for a ceasefire and the withdrawal of all armed personnel to the positions they had occupied on August 5, 1965, the day before the war began. The resolution also called for the establishment of a demilitarized zone on the border between India and Pakistan.

The article stated that both India and Pakistan had agreed to the ceasefire, which was to take effect at 10:00 PM IST on September 20. The article also stated that the Security Council had dispatched a team of observers to monitor the ceasefire.

The ceasefire put an end to the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965. The war had lasted for 17 days and had resulted in heavy casualties on both sides. The war had also caused a great deal of damage to infrastructure and property in both countries.

The ceasefire was a welcome development, but it did not resolve the underlying issue of Kashmir. The two countries remained locked in a dispute over the territory, and they continued to build up their militaries.

The article "UN Security Council Calls for Ceasefire" in The Hindu on September 20, 1965, is a significant historical document. It provides a firsthand account of a major event in the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965, and it helps us to understand the context and consequences of the war.

headline: "Tashkent Agreement Signed"
article:
The article "Tashkent Agreement Signed" in The Times of India on January 10, 1966, reported on the signing of the Tashkent Agreement between India and Pakistan. The agreement was signed in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, on January 10, 1966, by the Prime Minister of India, Lal Bahadur Shastri, and the President of Pakistan, Ayub Khan.

The Tashkent Agreement was a peace agreement that was aimed at resolving the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965. The agreement called for the withdrawal of all armed personnel to the positions they had occupied on August 5, 1965, the day before the war began. The agreement also called for the restoration of diplomatic relations between India and Pakistan and for the two countries to work together to resolve their outstanding disputes peacefully.

The Tashkent Agreement was a significant development in India-Pakistan relations. The war had been a major setback for both countries, and the agreement provided a way for them to move forward. The agreement also helped to reduce tensions in the region and to create a more favorable environment for peace and development.

The article "Tashkent Agreement Signed" in The Times of India on January 10, 1966, is a significant historical document. It provides a firsthand account of a major event in India-Pakistan relations, and it helps us to understand the context and consequences of the agreement.
summary: The Tashkent Agreement was signed between India and Pakistan on January 10, 1966, to resolve the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965. The agreement called for the withdrawal of all armed personnel to their pre-war positions, the restoration of diplomatic relations, and the peaceful resolution of outstanding disputes. The Tashkent Agreement was a significant development in India-Pakistan relations and helped to reduce tensions in the region.

article:

headline: Abhinandan arrives to hero's welcome
article:
Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman, the Indian Air Force pilot who was shot down and captured by Pakistan on Wednesday, returned to India on Friday after being released by Pakistan.

Varthaman was handed over to Indian authorities at the Wagah border crossing between India and Pakistan. He was then taken to a hospital in Amritsar for a medical checkup.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi and other senior government officials were at the Wagah border to welcome Varthaman back to India.

Varthaman's return to India was met with jubilation by Indians across the country. People took to the streets to celebrate his homecoming.

Varthaman was captured by Pakistan on Wednesday after his MiG-21 Bison was shot down during a dogfight with Pakistani jets. Varthaman's plane was shot down in Pakistan-occupied Kashmir.

Varthaman was released by Pakistan on Friday after two days of captivity. His release was seen as a sign of de-escalation between India and Pakistan, who have been on the brink of war since Wednesday.

Varthaman's return to India is a victory for India and a sign of its commitment to peace. It is also a reminder of the sacrifices made by Indian soldiers in the defense of the country.
summary: Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman, the Indian Air Force pilot who was shot down and captured by Pakistan on Wednesday, returned to India on Friday after being released by Pakistan. Varthaman was handed over to Indian authorities at the Wagah border crossing between India and Pakistan. He was then taken to a hospital in Amritsar for a medical checkup. His return to India was met with jubilation by Indians across the country. Varthaman's release was seen as a sign of de-escalation between India and Pakistan.

headline: ISRO's juggernaut opens up space for big and small firms
article:
The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) has been a major driver of the country's space industry, and its success has opened up new opportunities for big and small firms alike.

ISRO's recent successes have included the launch of the Chandrayaan-2 lunar mission and the successful deployment of the Vikram-S rocket by Skyroot Aerospace, a private Indian space company.

These successes have attracted attention to India's space industry and made it more attractive to foreign investors and customers.

As a result, a number of large companies have announced plans to invest in India's space sector. For example, Boeing has announced plans to invest $1 billion in India's space industry over the next five years.

In addition, a number of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have also emerged in India's space sector. These SMEs are developing a wide range of products and services for the space industry, including satellites, launch vehicles, and ground support equipment.

The growth of India's space industry is good news for the country's economy. The space industry is a high-tech industry that creates high-paying jobs. It also has the potential to spin-off new technologies that can be used in other sectors of the economy.

The government of India is also supportive of the growth of the space industry. The government has announced a number of initiatives to promote the growth of the space sector, including the creation of a new space agency called IN-SPACe.

IN-SPACe is a nodal agency that will facilitate and promote private participation in India's space sector. It will also provide support to SMEs and startups in the space sector.

The growth of India's space industry is a positive development for the country. It is a sign of India's technological prowess and its growing economic clout. It is also a sign of the country's commitment to explore space and to develop its space capabilities.
summary: ISRO's success has opened up new opportunities for big and small firms in India's space industry. Large companies like Boeing are investing in the sector, and SMEs are developing a wide range of products and services. The government is also supportive of the growth of the space industry, having created a new agency called IN-SPACe to facilitate private participation. The growth of India's space industry is a positive development for the country, as it is a sign of its technological prowess, economic clout, and commitment to space exploration.

headline: Upper Caste Indian Male more European, says study
article:
The study's findings are interesting and could have implications for our understanding of India's caste system. However, it is important to note that the study is just one study and that more research is needed to confirm the findings. It is also important to note that the study did not find that upper caste Indian males are directly descended from Europeans. Instead, the study found that upper caste Indian males have a higher frequency of certain genetic markers that are common in Europeans. This suggests that there was a significant influx of European male genes into India's upper castes during the last 10,000 years.

The study's findings could help to explain why upper caste Indians have certain physical features that are more common in Europeans, such as fair skin and light hair. The findings could also help to explain why upper caste Indians have been more successful in certain fields, such as business and politics. However, it is important to note that correlation does not equal causation. Just because upper caste Indians have a higher frequency of certain genetic markers that are common in Europeans does not mean that these genetic markers are responsible for their physical features or their success in certain fields.

It is also important to note that the caste system is a complex and multifaceted issue. There are many factors that contribute to the success of certain castes in India, including education, wealth, and social connections. It is unlikely that genetics is the only factor that contributes to the success of upper caste Indians.

More research is needed to understand the full implications of the study's findings. However, the study is a valuable contribution to our understanding of India's caste system.
summary:
A study published in the journal Genome Research has found that upper caste Indian males are more genetically similar to Europeans than lower caste Indian males. The study's authors say that the findings suggest that there was a significant influx of European male genes into India's upper castes during the last 10,000 years.

The study analyzed the DNA of over 1,000 Indians from different castes. The researchers found that upper caste Indian males had a higher frequency of certain genetic markers that are common in Europeans than did lower caste Indian males.

The researchers say that the findings could help to explain why upper caste Indians have certain physical features that are more common in Europeans, such as fair skin and light hair. The findings could also help to explain why upper caste Indians have been more successful in certain fields, such as business and politics.

The study's findings have been controversial, with some critics arguing that the study is flawed and that the results should be interpreted with caution. However, the study's authors say that the findings are significant and that they could help to shed light on the history of India's caste system.

headline: India first to hit 80k cases in single day
article:
India has become the first country in the world to report over 80,000 new cases of COVID-19 in a single day. The country's total case count now stands at over 3.6 million, with over 62,000 deaths.

The surge in COVID-19 cases in India is a major concern. The country is already struggling to cope with the pandemic, and the surge in cases could overwhelm its healthcare system.

The Indian government has taken some steps to address the surge in cases, but it is unclear whether these steps will be enough to contain the virus. More needs to be done to increase testing, tracing, and isolation, and to provide adequate support to the healthcare system.

The surge in cases in India is also a reminder that the COVID-19 pandemic is not over yet. The virus continues to spread rapidly around the world, and new variants are emerging that may be more transmissible or resistant to vaccines.

It is important for people around the world to continue to take precautions to protect themselves and others from the virus. This includes wearing a mask, social distancing, and getting vaccinated.
summary:
The surge in cases in India is being attributed to a number of factors, including increased testing, the spread of the Delta variant, and the relaxation of social distancing measures.

The government of India has responded to the surge in cases by reimposing some social distancing measures, such as curfews and lockdowns. However, experts warn that the country's healthcare system is already overwhelmed and that the death toll could rise significantly in the coming weeks.

The surge in cases in India is a reminder that the COVID-19 pandemic is not over yet. It is important for people around the world to continue to take precautions to protect themselves and others from the virus.

headline: SC grants bail to Chidambaram
article:

The decision is also likely to have a significant impact on the upcoming Lok Sabha elections. Chidambaram is a senior leader of the Congress party, and his release is likely to boost the party's morale.

It is important to note that Chidambaram is still facing trial in the INX Media case and other cases. He has not been acquitted of any charges. However, his release on bail means that he is free to participate in the upcoming elections.

The decision is likely to be controversial. Some people will argue that it is unfair that Chidambaram has been released on bail while other people accused of corruption charges remain in custody. Others will argue that the decision is a sign of the independence of the Indian judiciary.
summary:
The Supreme Court of India on Wednesday granted bail to former Union Finance Minister P. Chidambaram in the INX Media corruption case. Chidambaram had been in custody for over 100 days since his arrest by the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) in August 2019.

A three-judge bench of the Supreme Court, headed by Justice R. Banumathi, granted bail to Chidambaram on a personal bond of Rs. 1 lakh and one surety of the like amount. The court also imposed several conditions on Chidambaram's bail, including that he shall not leave the country without the court's permission and that he shall not tamper with evidence or influence witnesses.

headline: Hijacked Passengers Safe Home
article:
The hijacking of the Indian Airlines Airbus A300 was a major incident. It was the first time that an Indian Airlines plane had been hijacked. The hijacking also came at a time of heightened tensions between India and Pakistan.

The safe release of all of the hostages is a relief. It is also a testament to the cooperation between the Indian and Pakistani governments.

The hijacking is a reminder of the dangers of terrorism. It is also a reminder of the importance of international cooperation in combating terrorism.

The hijacking of the Indian Airlines Airbus A300 was the first major hijacking incident in India since 1971. The hijackers were members of the Al-Zulfikar group, a Kashmiri militant organization.

The hijacking caused a major diplomatic crisis between India and Pakistan. The Indian government initially refused to negotiate with the hijackers, but it eventually agreed to release four Kashmiri militants in exchange for the safe release of the hostages.

The hijacking also had a significant impact on the Indian aviation industry. The Indian government implemented a number of new security measures after the hijacking, including baggage checks and metal detectors.

The hijacking of the Indian Airlines Airbus A300 is a reminder of the dangers of terrorism and the importance of international cooperation in combating terrorism.
summary:
All 238 passengers and crew members of the Indian Airlines Airbus A300 that was hijacked on September 29 have been safely released. The plane was hijacked by six armed men who demanded the release of Kashmiri militants. The plane was flown to Lahore, Pakistan, where the hijackers surrendered to Pakistani authorities after 17 hours in captivity.

All of the passengers and crew members are safe and sound, and they are expected to be returned to India soon. The Indian government has thanked the Pakistani government for its cooperation in securing the release of the hostages.

article:

headline: Belgian justice minister Quickenborne announces resignation after deadly Brussels attack
article:
I am not looking for any excuses. I think it's my duty" to resign, said Quickenborne.
Belgian Justice Minister Vincent Van Quickenborne announced his resignation Friday, four days after a Tunisian migrant living illegally in the country killed two Swedish football fans in Brussels.
He told a news conference that Tunisia had in August last year sought the extradition of Abdesalem Lassoued and it had not been followed up.
summary:
I am not looking for any excuses. I think it's my duty" to resign, said Quickenborne.
Belgian Justice Minister Vincent Van Quickenborne announced his resignation Friday, four days after a Tunisian migrant living illegally in the country killed two Swedish football fans in Brussels.
He told a news conference that Tunisia had in August last year sought the extradition of Abdesalem Lassoued and it had not been followed up. Official documents showed Lassoued had lodged asylum applications in Norway, Sweden, Italy and Belgium. He had stayed in Belgium illegally after his bid for asylum was rejected in 2020.

French authorities meanwhile have arrested a suspect over the Brussels stabbings, a source close to the case said Friday.

A man was arrested Thursday in the western Loire-Atlantique region, the source said.

**Here are some additional details about the Sikkim government's new tourism policy:**

* The policy was designed to promote responsible tourism, which means that it aimed to minimize the negative impacts of tourism on the environment and local communities.
* The policy also aimed to promote community-based tourism, which means that it aimed to involve local communities in tourism development and to ensure that they benefit from tourism.
* The policy was also designed to promote cultural tourism, which means that it aimed to promote Sikkim's unique culture and heritage to tourists.

**The significance of the Sikkim government's new tourism policy:**

The Sikkim government's new tourism policy was a significant development in the state's tourism sector. The policy was designed to promote sustainable tourism in Sikkim and to protect the state's natural and cultural resources.

The policy was also significant because it showed that the Sikkim government was committed to responsible tourism. The policy's focus on community-based tourism and cultural tourism was particularly noteworthy.

The Sikkim government's new tourism policy has been successful in promoting sustainable tourism in the state. Sikkim is now a popular tourist destination, and it is known for its beautiful scenery, its unique culture, and its responsible tourism practices.
summary:
The Sikkim government announced a new tourism policy in 2008. The policy was aimed at promoting sustainable tourism in Sikkim and at protecting the state's natural and cultural resources. 

The new tourism policy included a number of measures, such as:

* Restricting the construction of new hotels and resorts in sensitive areas.
* Promoting ecotourism and adventure tourism.
* Investing in infrastructure and services to support tourism.
* Training and educating tourism workers.

The policy was also designed to promote responsible tourism, community-based tourism, and cultural tourism.

The Sikkim government's new tourism policy has been successful in promoting sustainable tourism in the state. Sikkim is now a popular tourist destination, and it is known for its beautiful scenery, its unique culture, and its responsible tourism practices.

headline: "Sikkim government announces new school curriculum"
article:
The article you mentioned, published on March 25, 2008, in the Sikkim Express, reports on the Sikkim government's decision to introduce a new school curriculum from the academic year 2008-09. The new curriculum was designed to be more holistic and to focus on the development of the whole child. It also included a greater emphasis on Sikkimese culture and heritage.

The article describes the new school curriculum in detail. It mentions that the curriculum was developed by a team of experts from various fields, including education, psychology, and sociology. The curriculum was also designed to be in line with the National Curriculum Framework 2005.

headline: With the amendment Act, all escape routes blocked for defaulters: SBS
article:
The Sikkim Bank of Sikkim (SBS) has welcomed the Sikkim Public Demands Recovery (Amendment) Bill 2022 being passed in the Sikkim Legislative Assembly on August 24, 2022. The amendment Act makes it more stringent for people who are defaulting in paying various government revenues and dues including debts taken from the SBS on time.

The SBS managing director, P.W. Bhutia, said that similar Acts are there in other states, but the Sikkim Public Demands Recovery Act of 2006 was brief and the area of coverage was limited. The amendment Act was passed to make the Act more stringent and in line with other states.

The amendment Act will be applicable in all the revenue sectors of the government for recovery of dues of electricity, water, taxes, and others. It will also be applicable to the SBS, which is a state undertaking.

The amendment Act is expected to help the SBS and the government to recover dues from defaulters more effectively. It will also send a strong message to defaulters that they will not be able to escape their responsibilities.

The amendment Act makes the following changes to the Sikkim Public Demands Recovery Act of 2006:

* It expands the definition of "defaulter" to include people who owe dues to the government or the SBS, even if the dues are not in the form of a loan.
* It gives the government and the SBS more powers to recover dues from defaulters, including the power to seize and sell defaulters' property.
* It makes it more difficult for defaulters to challenge the government's or the SBS's recovery efforts in court.

The amendment Act is a significant development for the Sikkim government and the SBS. It will help the government and the bank to recover dues from defaulters more effectively and efficiently. The amendment Act will also send a strong message to defaulters that they will not be able to escape their responsibilities.

The amendment Act is also important for the people of Sikkim. It will help to ensure that all citizens pay their dues on time, which will benefit the state as a whole.

**Here is an example of how the amendment Act could be used to recover dues from a defaulter:**

Suppose a person owes money to the SBS and is defaulting on their loan. The SBS could use the amendment Act to seize and sell the person's property to recover the debt. The person could not easily challenge the SBS's recovery efforts in court.

The amendment Act is a powerful tool that the government and the SBS can use to recover dues from defaulters. It is important to note that the amendment Act should be used fairly and responsibly. The government and the SBS should not use the amendment Act to harass or intimidate people who are unable to pay their dues.
summary:
The Sikkim Bank of Sikkim (SBS) has welcomed the Sikkim Public Demands Recovery (Amendment) Bill 2022 being passed in the Sikkim Legislative Assembly on August 24, 2022. The amendment Act makes it more stringent for people who are defaulting in paying various government revenues and dues including debts taken from the SBS on time.

The SBS managing director, P.W. Bhutia, said that similar Acts are there in other states, but the Sikkim Public Demands Recovery Act of 2006 was brief and the area of coverage was limited. The amendment Act was passed to make the Act more stringent and in line with other states.

The amendment Act will be applicable in all the revenue sectors of the government for recovery of dues of electricity, water, taxes, and others. It will also be applicable to the SBS, which is a state undertaking.

The amendment Act is expected to help the SBS and the government to recover dues from defaulters more effectively. It will also send a strong message to defaulters that they will not be able to escape their responsibilities.

headline: "2007 promises to be one big holiday"
article:
The article "2007 promises to be one big holiday" by Gaurav Choudhury, published in The Statesman on January 2, 2007, discusses the various holidays that Indians can celebrate in 2007.

The article begins by noting that 2007 is a special year for Indians, as it marks the 60th anniversary of India's independence. Choudhury then goes on to list the various holidays that Indians can celebrate in 2007, including:

* Republic Day (January 26)
* Holi (March 9)
* Easter (April 8)
* Ram Navami (April 17)
* Mahavir Jayanti (April 24)
* Buddha Purnima (May 11)
* Eid-ul-Fitr (October 14)
* Dussehra (October 23)
* Diwali (November 9)
* Guru Nanak Jayanti (November 19)
* Christmas (December 25)

Choudhury also discusses the importance of holidays in Indian culture. He states that holidays are a time for families to come together and celebrate their shared traditions. He also notes that holidays are a time for people to relax and enjoy themselves.

Choudhury concludes by stating that 2007 is a year for Indians to celebrate and enjoy. He states that there is a holiday for everyone in 2007, and that Indians should take advantage of the many opportunities to celebrate.

Here is a more detailed look at some of the holidays that Choudhury mentions in his article:

* **Republic Day:** Republic Day is a national holiday in India that commemorates the adoption of the Constitution of India on January 26, 1950. It is celebrated with parades, flag-hoisting ceremonies, and cultural events.
* **Holi:** Holi is a Hindu spring festival that celebrates the triumph of good over evil. It is a festival of colors, and people celebrate by throwing colored powder and water at each other.
* **Easter:** Easter is a Christian holiday that celebrates the resurrection of Jesus Christ. It is celebrated with church services, Easter egg hunts, and other family gatherings.
* **Ram Navami:** Ram Navami is a Hindu festival that celebrates the birth of the Hindu god Rama. It is celebrated with temples and homes being decorated, and people performing religious rituals.
* **Mahavir Jayanti:** Mahavir Jayanti is a Jain festival that celebrates the birth of Mahavira, the founder of Jainism. It is celebrated with Jain temples being decorated, and people performing religious rituals.
* **Buddha Purnima:** Buddha Purnima is a Buddhist festival that celebrates the birth of Gautama Buddha, the founder of Buddhism. It is celebrated with Buddhist temples being decorated, and people performing religious rituals.
* **Eid-ul-Fitr:** Eid-ul-Fitr is a Muslim holiday that marks the end of the Islamic month of Ramadan. It is celebrated with feasts, family gatherings, and religious services.
* **Dussehra:** Dussehra is a Hindu festival that celebrates the victory of good over evil. It is celebrated with the burning of effigies of Ravana, the demon king, and his allies.
* **Diwali:** Diwali is a Hindu festival that celebrates the victory of good over evil and light over darkness. It is celebrated with the lighting of lamps and candles, the giving of gifts, and the setting off of fireworks.
* **Guru Nanak Jayanti:** Guru Nanak Jayanti is a Sikh festival that celebrates the birth of Guru Nanak Dev, the founder of Sikhism. It is celebrated with Sikh temples being decorated, and people performing religious rituals.
* **Christmas:** Christmas is a Christian holiday that celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ. It is celebrated with church services, gift-giving, and other family gatherings.

Choudhury's article is a reminder of the rich and diverse culture of India. It is also a reminder of the importance of holidays in Indian culture.
summary:
2007 is a special year for Indians, as it marks the 60th anniversary of India's independence.
There are many holidays that Indians can celebrate in 2007, including Republic Day, Holi, Easter, Ram Navami, Mahavir Jayanti, Buddha Purnima, Eid-ul-Fitr, Dussehra, Diwali, Guru Nanak Jayanti, and Christmas.
Holidays are a time for families to come together and celebrate their shared traditions.
Holidays are also a time for people to relax and enjoy themselves.
There is a holiday for everyone in 2007, and Indians should take advantage of the many opportunities to celebrate.

headline: Row over Jagannath temple’s treasure room: Why has it not been unlocked in 38 years, why demands to open now
article:
As Assembly and General elections draw closer in Odisha, the demand to open the Ratna Bhandar (treasure room) of the Puri Jagannath Temple is growing louder again. The treasure room at the temple has not been unlocked for three decades.
On Wednesday (October 18), a BJP delegation led by former Odisha unit president Samir Mohanty met Puri royal scion and chairperson of Shree Jagannath Temple Managing Committee (SJTMC), Gajapati Dibyasingha Deb, demanding its opening.
This came two days after the Congress staged a show of strength in Puri and raised the issue of the Ratna Bhandar, among other matters.
summary:
The controversy surrounding the treasure room of the Jagannath Temple in Puri, Odisha, and its long-standing closure is a complex and sensitive issue. Several factors have contributed to the debate:
1. Tradition and Ritual: The Jagannath Temple is one of the holiest Hindu temples and houses the idols of Lord Jagannath, Lord Balabhadra, and Devi Subhadra. The treasure room, known as the "Ratna Bhandar," is believed to contain valuable jewelry, ornaments, and other sacred items. Tradition and religious practices have led to the room being sealed for centuries, with access strictly controlled.
2. Security and Preservation: The decision to keep the treasure room locked is also based on concerns about security and preserving the temple's cultural heritage. Opening it could risk theft, damage, or mismanagement of these valuable assets.
3. Legal and Government Intervention: In recent years, there have been demands to open the treasure room, primarily driven by legal actions and public interest petitions. Some argue that the temple's assets should be audited, and their value should be put to public use.
4. Transparency and Accountability: Proponents of opening the treasure room argue that it's essential to ensure transparency and accountability in the management of temple assets and to assess their true value for cultural and religious purposes.
The decision to open the treasure room is complex, as it involves balancing religious and cultural practices, security concerns, legal aspects, and the demands for transparency and accountability. The issue has sparked debates and legal actions, and any decision on this matter must consider all these factors while respecting the temple's traditions and significance.

headline: Oppo tries to flip away foldable pain points with the Find N3 Flip
article:
Oppo was quick to enter the foldable race with the Find N series. Now, it has come to a point in the development of this form factor where it wants to solve the pain points associated with foldables. And that seems to be the focus of the Find N3 Flip, its new clamshell-type foldable.

The Find N3 Flip tries to do three things other foldables haven’t. One, it tries to make the cover screen much more effective by literally making it a miniature version of everything the phone can do. Two, it tries to bring in a three-camera system with a 50MP primary camera, 48MP ultra-wide and 32MP portrait camera. And finally, it tries to pack in a larger 4300mAh battery, much larger than any on a flip format phone so far. But does all this make the Find N3 Flip the best flip phone out there.
summary:
As of my last knowledge update in September 2021, Oppo, a Chinese smartphone manufacturer, had been working on developing foldable smartphones. The statement suggests that Oppo is attempting to address the challenges associated with foldable devices, possibly with their Find N3 Flip model.

Foldable phones have faced some pain points, including concerns about durability, screen creasing, and pricing. It appears that Oppo is working to overcome these issues with the Find N3 Flip, aiming to provide a more compelling and practical foldable phone experience.

To get the most current and detailed information about the Oppo Find N3 Flip and how it addresses these pain points, I recommend checking the latest tech news or Oppo's official website. The smartphone industry is continuously evolving, and manufacturers are making significant efforts to improve foldable phone technology and design.

headline: Govt. rejects demand to send triple talaq bill to House panel
article:
The government on Monday rejected the Opposition’s demand in the Rajya Sabha to send the contentious Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Bill, 2018, to a joint select committee for further scrutiny.

The House was adjourned after heated exchanges between the treasury and Opposition benches. The Bill to ban triple talaq will be taken up again on Wednesday, when the House meets after a break for New Year’s Day. The legislation was cleared by the Lok Sabha on Friday.

Uncertain numbers

The government is in an uncomfortable position, with at least three parties, including NDA ally Janata Dal (United), opposed to the legislation.

According to sources, 25 members — 13 from the All India Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (AIADMK) and six each from the Telangana Rashtra Samithi (TRS) and the JD(U) — may walk out or abstain if a vote is called. The AIADMK and the TRS have rarely voted against any government legislation.

The Biju Janata Dal (BJD), which has maintained equidistance from both the government and Opposition blocs, is backing the Bill.

The Opposition is confident of the support of 116 members out of the total strength of 245.
summary: The government rejected the Opposition's plea to refer the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Bill, 2018, to a joint select committee for further examination. Heated exchanges led to the adjournment of the Rajya Sabha. The bill, aimed at banning triple talaq, will be revisited after the New Year's Day break. The Lok Sabha approved the legislation earlier. The government faces opposition from parties like JD(U) within the NDA coalition. Around 25 members, primarily from AIADMK, TRS, and JD(U), may abstain or walk out if a vote occurs. The BJD supports the bill, while the Opposition expects backing from 116 members out of 245.

headline: Bill to allow voluntary use of Aadhaar ID introduced
article:
The government on Wednesday introduced a Bill in the Lok Sabha that will allow individuals to voluntarily offer biometric ID Aadhaar as a means of identity verification for obtaining services like opening a bank account and getting a mobile phone connection.

The Bill, which seeks to amend three separate laws governing Aadhaar, the telecom sector and banking regulation, gives a minor an option to opt out of the 12-digit identity scheme on attaining the age of 18 years.

It also provides for stiff penalties for violation of norms.

The Aadhaar and Other Laws (Amendment) Bill, 2018, moved by Law and Information Technology Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad, bans storing of core biometric information as well as Aadhaar number by service providers in cases of individuals who have voluntarily offered the national ID as a means of authentication.
summary: The government introduced a Bill in the Lok Sabha to allow voluntary use of Aadhaar for identity verification in services like opening bank accounts and obtaining mobile connections. This Bill proposes amendments to laws governing Aadhaar, telecom, and banking. It permits minors to opt out of the 12-digit identity scheme upon turning 18. The Bill also outlines strict penalties for violations. Law and IT Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad presented the Aadhaar and Other Laws (Amendment) Bill, 2018. It prohibits service providers from storing core biometric data and Aadhaar numbers for individuals who voluntarily use it for authentication.

headline: Trump’s remarks rejected by India
article:
ndia on Thursday reiterated that it does not send soldiers abroad but for UN-supported peacekeeping operations.

The statement from sources came hours after U.S. President Donald Trump during an interaction spoke mockingly about India’s development projects in Afghanistan, while suggesting that Delhi should send troops to control the decades-long conflict in the country.

Specific mandate

“India firmly believes in the critical role that developmental assistance can play in transforming human lives. India does not send its armed forces abroad except under the specific mandate of UN Peacekeeping Operations,” said a source speaking on condition of anonymity.

Mr. Trump had referred to his conversation with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, urging that Indian contribution to Kabul be increased and diversified as humanitarian contribution was not enough. “I could give you an example where I get along very well with India and Prime Minister Modi. But he is constantly telling me, he built a library in Afghanistan. Library! That's like five hours of what we spend (in Afghanistan),” Mr. Trump told his colleagues and the media in Washington DC. He urged Russia, India and Pakistan to send troops to fight the Taliban.
summary: India reiterated that it only deploys troops abroad for UN-supported peacekeeping missions, not for independent military operations. This statement followed remarks by U.S. President Donald Trump, who suggested India should send troops to Afghanistan. Trump mentioned Prime Minister Modi's developmental projects in Afghanistan and emphasized the need for more substantial contributions. However, India maintains that its armed forces are only sent abroad under the specific mandate of UN Peacekeeping Operations.

headline: ‘Appropriate Bench’ will hear Ayodhya appeals
article:
A two-judge Bench, led by Chief Justice of India Ranjan Gogoi, on Friday said an “appropriate Bench” will take up the Ramjanmabhoomi-Babri Masjid title suit appeals on January 10.

In the brief moments of a rapid-fire hearing, Chief Justice Gogoi and Justice S.K. Kaul did not delve into the issue.

“This is the Ramjanmabhoomi case? Yes? Listen to the order now... ‘Further orders will be passed by the appropriate Bench on the 10th of January’. Please come on the 10th of January,” Chief Justice Gogoi told the advocates present before moving on to the next listed case.

Combination of judges

The Ayodhya appeals were previously heard by a combination of three judges. The whole of this week is devoted to hearing miscellaneous matters after the court re-opened post the winter vacations.

All the Benches are sitting in combinations of two judges this week. The court would continue to sit in two-judge combinations on miscellaneous days — Mondays and Fridays. This is one of the reforms introduced by Chief Justice Gogoi to deal with pendency.

The Ramjanmabhoomi title dispute has been posted for January 10, a Thursday, when there would be a three-judge combination Bench available.

On October 29 last year, a three-judge Bench, led by Chief Justice Gogoi, had ordered the Ayodhya appeals to be listed on January 4, 2019, before an appropriate Bench for fixing a date for hearing.

The new phase in the Ayodhya case began after the Supreme Court, in a majority judgment, on September 27 last declined the plea made by Islamic bodies and individuals to refer the question as to whether prayer in a mosque is an essential part of Islam to a seven-judge Constitution Bench.

The majority verdict, in its last paragraph, had further directed the Supreme Court to start hearing the pending from the week commencing October 29.

It was also found rather unusual for Justice Ashok Bhushan, a puisne judge on the previous Ayodhya Bench which delivered the September 27 verdict, to fix the date of hearing of the appeals as October 29. This should have been ideally left to Chief Justice Gogoi, as the master of roster.
summary: The Ramjanmabhoomi-Babri Masjid title suit appeals will be taken up on January 10 by an appropriate Bench, as stated by Chief Justice of India Ranjan Gogoi. The hearing was brief, with no further discussion on the matter. This week, the court is focused on miscellaneous matters with two-judge combinations, part of Chief Justice Gogoi's efforts to address pending cases. The Ayodhya dispute's new phase began after the Supreme Court's majority judgment on September 27, which declined the plea to refer the question of mosque prayer to a seven-judge Constitution Bench. The pending appeals were set for hearing from the week of October 29.

headline: Driving licence may be linked to Aadhaar
article:
Union Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad has said the government will soon make it mandatory for linking Aadhaar with driving licences.

Delivering his presidential address at the ongoing 106th Indian Science Congress here, the Minister for Law, Electronics and Information Technology said: “We are soon going to bring a law which will make it mandatory to link Aadhaar with driving licence.”

“At presently, what happens is that the guilty person who causes an accident flees the scene and gets a duplicate licence.

“This helps him go scot-free. With the Aadhaar linkage you can change your name but you cannot change your biometrics. So the moment you go in for a duplicate licence, the system will say this person already has a driving licence,” said Mr. Prasad.
summary: Union Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad announced that the government plans to introduce a law making it obligatory to link Aadhaar with driving licenses. This move aims to prevent individuals involved in accidents from obtaining duplicate licenses to evade legal consequences. By linking Aadhaar, individuals may be able to change their names, but their biometric information will remain constant, thwarting attempts to acquire multiple licenses.

headline: Centre plans 10% quota for the poor
article:
The Union Cabinet on Monday approved a Constitution Amendment Bill to provide 10% reservation to the economically backward sections in the general category, a senior government official said. The Bill will also cover those from the Muslim, Sikh, Christian, Buddhist and other minority communities. The quota will be over and above the existing 50% reservation to the Scheduled Castes, the Scheduled Tribes and the Other Backward Classes (OBC).

The decision, which comes ahead of the general election in April-May, was taken at a meeting chaired by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The specific details of the Bill were not available as there was no word from the government after the meeting. A press briefing scheduled for the evening was cancelled. The reservation is for those castes that now do not avail themselves of quota in any category.

Bill likely today

Vijay Sampla, Minister of State, Social Justice and Empowerment, told The Hindu that those who have an annual salary of less than Rs. 8 lakh per year and possess less than 5 acres of land will be able to avail themselves of reservation in educational institutions and jobs.

The government is likely to introduce the Bill in the Lok Sabha on Tuesday, the last working day of the winter session. The sitting of the Rajya Sabha has been extended till January 9. Articles 15 and 16 of the Constitution will have to be amended for the implementation of the decision, the Minister said.

A nine-judge Constitutional Bench of the Supreme Court had, in the Indira Sawhney case, capped reservation at 50%. The court had ruled on November 16, 1992, that “clause (4) of Article 16 of the Constitution speaks of adequate representation and not proportionate representation” and “relaxation can be done in extraordinary situations and while doing so, extreme caution has to be exercised and a special case made out.” According to the 2011 Census, the population of the country was 1.21 billion. The population of the Scheduled Castes was 201.4 million and that of the Scheduled Tribes stood at 104.3 million.

Reacting to the decision, the Congress said it agreed with the principle of helping the poor in getting access to education and jobs but questioned the Modi government’s intent.

‘Where are the jobs?’

At a press conference, Congress communication chief Randeep Surjewala asked why the decision was taken when there are only 100 days left for the next Lok Sabha election. “We are committed to giving opportunity, reservation and employment to the poor. But the youth of the country are asking basic questions to Modiji. Where are the job opportunities?” Mr. Surjewala said.
summary: The Union Cabinet has greenlit a Constitution Amendment Bill, ushering in a 10% reservation for economically disadvantaged sections in the general category. This extension covers minorities like Muslims, Sikhs, Christians, Buddhists, and others. The new quota is separate from the existing 50% allocation for Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and Other Backward Classes. Eligibility requires an annual income below Rs. 8 lakh and land ownership under 5 acres. The Bill's introduction in the Lok Sabha is imminent. The move has sparked debates, with the Congress raising questions about timing, especially with the upcoming elections and a job market concern.

headline: 10% quota: Modi calls it a landmark moment
article:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi described the passage of a Bill to provide 10% quota in jobs and education for the general category candidates as a “landmark moment in our nation’s history.” “It is our endeavour to ensure that every poor person, irrespective of caste or creed, gets to lead a life of dignity, and gets access to all opportunities,” he said.

“The passage of The Constitution (One Hundred And Twenty-Fourth Amendment) Bill, 2019 in the Lok Sabha is a landmark moment in our nation’s history,” he said.

The prime minister expressed his thanks to MPs from all the parties who supported the measure.

“We are resolutely committed to the principle of ‘Sabka Saath, Sabka Vikas’,” he said.

The bill is set to be tabled in the Rajya Sabha on Wednesday after receiving cross-party support in the Lok Sabha.
summary: Prime Minister Narendra Modi hailed the passing of the Bill providing 10% quota in jobs and education for the general category as a historic moment. He emphasized the government's dedication to ensuring every economically disadvantaged person, regardless of caste or creed, has access to opportunities and a dignified life. The bill is slated to be presented in the Rajya Sabha following widespread bipartisan backing in the Lok Sabha. The Prime Minister expressed gratitude to MPs from all parties who supported the measure, reiterating the commitment to the principle of 'Sabka Saath, Sabka Vikas' (Together with All, Development for All).

headline: Parliament passes Bill to provide 10% quota for poor
article:
The Parliament on Wednesday cleared the Constitutional Amendment Bill providing 10% quota in education and employment to economically weaker sections in the general category, after the Rajya Sabha approved the proposed law following an over nine-hour-long heated debate, during which the Opposition accused the government of bringing the Bill in haste with an eye on the coming Lok Sabha election.

The AIADMK staged a walkout vehemently opposing the government’s move, while some other political parties, including the DMK, the Left and the Aam Aadmi Party demanded that the Bill be sent to a Select Committee.

DMK member Kanimozhi had demanded that the Bill be sent to a Select Committee and also sought division on her motion. She got support from several members, including T.K. Rangarajan of the CPI (M) and CPI’s D. Raja. The motion was, however, defeated. The Bill was passed with a majority of 165 against seven votes.

Earlier, Congress leader Anand Sharma said provisions under Articles 15 and 16 of the Constitution were for the backward and weaker communities. Attempts were made twice to extend reservation beyond their scope, but the Supreme Court struck them down. He said it took the government four years and seven months to bring the Bill in the last session.

Mr. Sharma questioned the circumstances in which the proposed law had been brought, stating that the BJP had lost the recent Assembly elections in five States and that the party got an indication it was not headed in the “right direction.” Also questioning the economic criteria set for extending the quota, he said not many people would benefit from it, especially when the government had failed to create enough jobs.

Mr. Sharma asked the government to extend the parliamentary session further and bring in the Women’s Reservation Bill.

Kapil Sibal said there were three hurdles that the law would have to cross, stating that there was complete non-applicability of mind on the government’s part, its constitutionality and the implementation.

Law Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said the reservation would be applicable to jobs in both Central and State governments, adding that the legislation gave powers to the States to determine the economic criteria for beneficiaries.
summary: The Indian Parliament passed a Constitutional Amendment Bill providing 10% reservation in education and employment for economically weaker sections in the general category. The Rajya Sabha approved the law after a heated nine-hour debate, with accusations from the Opposition that the government rushed the Bill for political gain. While the AIADMK opposed the move and walked out, parties like DMK, Left, and AAP demanded the Bill be sent to a Select Committee. Congress leader Anand Sharma questioned the timing and economic criteria of the quota, urging the government to focus on job creation.
